Thank you for supporting us during this incredibly challenging time.I would like to thank everybody who voted for me in the Scottish election and the many people who helped my campaign.I congratulate Jenni Minto on her election and wish her well in her job of representing the people of Argyll and Bute at Holyrood.The following is an open letter from John Gurr, chairperson of the Rest and Be Thankful Campaign group, to Transport Scotland#s chief executive, Roy Brannen, and director of roads, Hugh Gillies, in response to a follow-up email following a meeting held with officials from the transport agency last month. Dear Roy and Hugh,I am writing in response to an official Transport Scotlandemail to the Rest and Be ThankfulCampaign on April  , where you have sought to answer several questions posed by us at our meeting with your officials and in subsequent emails to you both. We are hugely disappointed by this response and its apparent contradictions.We asked for a permanent solution within the next three years. The email states: #We are not waiting for anything and are pushing on with work at pace#, yet your actions since the August landslide have only created delay.Creating  options for consultation in November , this, we believe, is a time-wasting exercise. Five further options for consultation in March. We strongly believe there are only three real options, with studies on these completed in your  report. Conducting a geological survey which will take eighteen months to complete, a process that could have started last August, assuming you had not conducted such surveys in .We have asked for temporary use of the forestry road, away from the threats posed by landsides. It also states: #We were clear without that information we are not certain the forestry track in its current form is safe for use.# Yet we would argue you already have a Transerv report produced in  by Balfour Beatty and Mouchal Services Ltd for TS which suggested the forestry road could be upgraded in  to  weeks. How did Transerv arrive at this conclusion without a study of the ground conditions being done in advance This situation should be considered a safety, economic and social emergency, cutting through the red tape of consultation and delay. It further declares: #We understand first-hand the delay that can be caused by procedural challenge…there needs to be a careful balancing of accelerating development and procedural risk in order to ensure that we do not end up in the courts.#While we understand the need for the right balance of speed and consultation, we think the safety risks, costs incurred by business and damage to the economy of Argyll, should create the conditions for emergency action, delivering what should be a simple road realignment. This is not HS, we are not asking to blight the countryside, or people#s homes, you do not have whole communities ready to challenge fixing the crisis at RABT.What we want cannot be worse than the damage already inflicted on the hillside without consultation. If you fixed the Rest, we will all be thankful.The following questions still have not been answered in TS#s official reply or in recent press statements:We are business people and understand the need for safe environments, effective procedures, timely management, and cost control, but what we have experienced over the past year does not give us confidence you will address the concerns we have.We are not looking for you to defend your approach, what matters to us is the action taken to bring timescales down and resolve the problem within the next parliament. We are simply asking you to rethink your approach, look at how your team can cut through this #business as usual# process and appoint someone who can find a way to realign two kilometres of the A safely within the next three years.By challenging your approach, we are hoping to see that after nearly a year of delay and ersion, there is a recognition of the cost impact to business, the signicant safety concerns, and that this will continue to blight Argyll as a place to live, work, and invest in until a permanent solution is delivered.We will be working with the relevant politicians post elections and will continue to campaign for a change in approach. We would be happy to discuss what can be done to overcome any constraints you have to deliver a solution quickly and resolve the crisis at the RABT.We stand at a once-in-a-generation crossroads.Earlier this week, a thought-provoking poem, ACCEPTABLE  by the Anonymous Mother # judged for needing a food bank to feed her child # started a nationwide debate about whether the world#s fth richest country should need food banks to feed children.This conversation needed to happen as our food bank crisis has become critical.Last year food banks in the Trussell Trust#s network handed out , emergency food parcels for children in the UK. This surely cannot be acceptable.However, fate has given us a rare opportunity, as history shows us that the best time to create a brighter future is after times of great darkness.The pandemic has been the most devastating event to hit our country since the Second World War, but it also brought out the very best of our nation.We recognised our real community heroes, we protected the vulnerable, we didn#t stand by when kids went hungry.But now, as we prepare to wake up from the pandemic nightmare, millions of British families still cannot afford food on their table.As the Anonymous Mother poetically says # it doesn#t need to be this way.In , Britain woke up to its new dawn at a similar crossroads # go back to the old broken way, or use this golden opportunity to make things better.That great generation chose hope, and created a better, fairer society for all # including founding the NHS.This pandemic has been our generation#s darkest hour. This is now our new dawn, our choice. Will we choose the old broken way, or use this golden opportunity to eradicate hunger in the UK I urge you to do just one thing today, and that is to seek out the poem that started all of this, and reflect.If, afterwards, you agree with me and the hundreds of thousands of other supporters of the Trussell Trust, that we can do better, join us as we collectively create a #hunger free future#.

Thank you for supporting us during this incredibly challenging time.As the anniversary of the battle of St Valéry-en-Caux approaches, an international search has been launched to uncover the identity of a fallen hero.The soldier of the st Highland Division evaded capture during the infamous Second World War battle, in which almost  men from Kintyre fought, but would later be discovered and now rests in an unnamed grave.Days after the mass evacuations at Dunkirk, thousands of men from the st Highland Division remained on mainland Europe supporting their French allies. As German troops advanced through Normandy, the st fought valiantly, protecting French citizens, hoping evacuation by sea would be forthcoming.On June  , German tanks surrounded the ision at the French fishing port of St Valéry. This, alongside a curtain of heavy fog, made the long-awaited flotilla rescue unviable and they were forced to surrender. Those who were not killed in the fighting were captured as prisoners of war and marched to camps in Eastern Europe, where they remained for five gruelling years.Following the commemorations to mark the th anniversary of the battle last June, a remarkable story has emerged. One brave soldier miraculously evaded capture and was taken in by a French family who hid him from the occupying German forces.#We were contacted by Monsieur Patrick Prieur, a -year-old St Valéry resident whose grandparents and father remained in the town during the entirety of the war. He told us the story of the escapee and the tragedy that befell him,# said Dr Claire Armstrong, chief executive of Legion Scotland.#As we approach the st anniversary of the battle, we hope to identy this Scottish hero, give him the recognition he deserves and bring peace to his family.#Patrick Prieur recalled the tale his late father told him: #A soldier from the st Highland Division was hidden by a family in the village. They bonded and the family learned he was a married man with a we and two daughters waiting for him tohome.#For several weeks, the soldier remained hidden but, regretfully, he was eventually discovered by German troops and marched through the town to the municipal cemetery.#After being forced to dig his own grave, he was positioned against the cemetery wall and shot. His death deeply upset the townspeople, who had been aware of his hiding, and especially my father, who was only  at the time.#In later years, the Franco-British military cemetery was built and his body was moved there. His grave is marked as #Known unto God# and my father and other villagers tended to it for decades after the war ended.#Monsieur Prieur added: #My father had been gted a piece of paper on which the soldier#s name was written, #Keller Len Scott#, and this became his prized possession. He desperately wanted to find the soldier#s family to tell them what had happened to their beloved and where he was laid to rest, but having very little information, he struggled.#In  my father passed away and, being eager to finish what he started, I recently contacted Poppyscotland and the Highland Reserve Forces# and Cadets# Association to ask for help.#Michelle McKearnon, head of engagement at the Highland Reserve Forces# and Cadets# Association, said: #We started to do our own research to unearth the fallen soldier#s identity but only got so far. We believe the name order on the piece of paper may have been written in military fashion, with the surname preceding any given names, so the family name might be Keller.#We#re now at an impasse, struggling to find additional information through our own resources, so we need the knowledge of the wider community to continue our efforts.#Dr Armstrong added: #We are urging anyone who believes they know of or has any information about our #Unknown Soldier#, no matter how small, to get in touch.#This brave man fought valiantly for his country and to repay our debt to him for his service would be an honour, not only for Legion Scotland as custodians of remembrance, but for his family, Monsieur Prieur#s father, the people of St Valéry and, ultimately, for all the #unknown soldiers# who sacriced their lives for us.#Anyone with information that could help identy the soldier should visit poppyscotland.org.uk stvalery

Thank you for supporting us during this incredibly challenging time.A classic British racing yacht and her crew were saved from being dashed onto the rocks of the Mull of Kintyre on Saturday night by Campbeltown#s leboats during a six-hour rescue operation.The yacht was competing in the Scottish Islands Peak Race.The rudder of the ft-long Sceptre had broken and Force Six winds from the northwest were driving her onto clfs below the lighthouse.Campbeltown#s Severn-class leboat was launched with the inshore leboat following. They did notto the harbour until after pm with the casualty in tow.The following day, Sceptre skipper Tom Smith praised the hard work and efficiency of the Campbeltown leboat crews.Diver Robert Lamont, a member of the leboat crew the night before, went in and removed the damaged rudder ready for Sceptre to be towed by tug to Troon, the finish of the race.The race sails from Oban to Mull, Jura and Arran then Troon, stopping at each island for a team of runners to complete a hill race.Sceptre, with a crew of four, was carrying the boys# team from Glenalmond School, Perth.She had run aground the night before entering Craighouse, Jura. Everything looked fine on the yacht, which was built in Argyll at Alexander Robertson#s Holy Loch yard to compete in the America#s Cup of .#As a precaution, we did not have the boys on board for the tough leg round the Mull of Kintyre to Arran,# said crew member Roger Finbow.#They haven#t missed the race they were on board Blue Damsel, carrying the girls# team.#The decision proved a wise move as not only did the rudder come loose leaving the yacht with no steering, it was flapping wildly and in danger of damaging the hull.As a precaution, the leboat crew put a heavy-duty pump on board but this was not needed.HMS Dragon broke off her sea trials to come to the aid of Sceptre. The Type  Clyde-built destroyer stood by until the leboat arrived.TWENTY-FIVE YEARS AGOCalls were mounting earlier this week for a Scottish Office decision on the proposed ferry link between Campbeltown and Northern Ireland.The Scottish Office has been considering a business plan for state-owned Caledonian MacBrayne to operate the link with Ballycastle in Northern Ireland since the beginning of February.The company needs Scottish Office permission to become involved in the project.But concern is growing that unless a decision is made soon the necessary harbour work at Campbeltown will not start until it is too late for the service to begin next year.Two Campbeltown ambulance men were among six from Argyll recently presented with long service and good conduct medals by the Duke of Argyll.Ronnie Hamilton and Malcolm Black travelled to Oban for the presentation, carried out by the Duke on behalf of HM Queen.The medals are not awarded automatically but are made on the recommendation of a special .The Duke told the ambulance men: #What you do is not a profession, it is a vocation.#He also paid tribute to their families, pointing out the ambulance men worked anti-social hours for long periods at a time.FIFTY YEARS AGOCampbeltown was #switched on# to colour television on Tuesday by the town#s new Provost, William Craig, in his first official engagement.The service has been brought to Campbeltown by Redfusion, the firm which pipes television to several thousand subscribers from its mast at Crosshill Farm.The firm#s Scottish general manager Mr Colin Payne said that Redfusion offers a public service of which they were proud.#We looked at the television problems here. There were just BBC and STV and occasionally Ulster in the town.#We said can we bring to Campbeltown the full range of colour programmes which are available where and the answer to that was #yes#.#There are now six programmes on the system. There aren#t many places in the country which can receive this.#ONE HUNDRED YEARS AGOAn English steam liner which called in here for bait one day last week had full bunkers and a plentul reserve of coal in ious corners. She had gone to Ostende for the fuel.A further restriction of the gas supply in the burgh comes into force on Saturday night. The hours during which there will be reduced and normal pressure respectively are given in advertisement.The local branch of the Miners# Union opened a subscription list this week for the purpose of starting a communal soup kitchen. It is not intended, of course, to confine the benefits of the scheme to miners or their dependents. Over £ has already been raised and the committee intend to publish the list of subscriptions next week.A welcome break in our comparative isolation from the mainland was made at the beginning of the week when the steamer Kinloch made a special run to the upper reaches, with mail, passengers and cargo.Many merchants, not only in Campbeltown but at Carradale and the west of Arran ports, were carrying very low stocks and this run was not made a day too soon to prevent absolute scarcity of not a few necessities.Flour, for one thing, was running very short, and the new supplies got by bakers were very much-needed.Alcohol is again tipped as a likely rival to petrol. The new motor fuel is being produced by the Distillers Company Ltd and consists of a mixture of  per cent of alcohol,  per cent of benzole and  per cent of paraffin. The idea of using alcohol is not new, but a fatal obstacle has been the unwillingness of the government to release its hold upon alcohol and permit it to be used for commercial purposes.

Thank you for supporting us during this incredibly challenging time.I have been reading a lot of reports and letters in national and local newspapers about the problems experienced at the Rest and Be Thankful.I have no doubt that those charged with keeping the trunk road operational and safe for drivers are doing their best in the circumstances.However, there now seems to be an acceptance in Transport Scotland that a new solution has to be found.In a letter to the press, George Allan points out that the -mile route from Strathlachlan to Colintraive and the eight miles between Ormidale and Tighnabruaich were designed and constructed in  or  years.I was a member of the survey and design team on these routes. I was also involved in the construction of  miles of the A between Perth and Inverness in  years. These civil engineering schemes demonstrate what can be achieved when there is real political will and commitment to prioritise projects.I realise Transport Scotland has its own procedures for appointing consultants for the design processes and there are detailed environmental impact assessments to be done. It does, however, seem to me that its programming of the Rest and Be Thankful improvement is completely lacking in ambition.As a former director of roads and transport in Highland, perhaps I may be permitted to comment on the long-term solution.I would saythere are no geological features found on the other side of the glen which will cause a repeat of current problems, then the construction of a new road in ersion would cause less disruption to traffic than trying to form landslip shelters or tunnels adjacent to the existing carriageway.The main thing though is for Transport Scotland and their political masters to just get on with it.This week, Scotland#s Charity Air Ambulancemarks its eighth anniversary – after a year like no other.Throughout the coronavirus pandemic, our Helimed crews have never missed a beat maintaining our emergency helicopter air ambulance service across Scotland#s mainland and island communities. In fact we#ve enhanced our service with the launch of a new aircraft – Helimed  in Aberdeen last year – which has already had a huge impact on pre-hospital care in the Grampian, Highland and island regions.In our busiest year ever, our aircrew have endured challenging working conditions, with additional procedures and cumbersome protective and safety equipment as they go about an already dficult and stressful job.But they#re not complaining – this is what the Scottish public ask of them, to save and improve lives, wherever the need arises, and they fulfil their role with courage and pride.Our exemplary performance during this national crisis has been a tribute to how far SCAA has come in just eight years and I, for one, am immensely proud of what the SCAA team has achieved.But our operational teams are acutely aware that we are only able to provide this critical service, thanks to the continued public donations which you have maintained throughout these dficult times. So you are the real heroes in our charity.SCAA is the people#s helicopter – funded by the people of Scotland, for the people of Scotland – and our two frontline aircraft are stood by ready to help you, your family, your friends, colleagues, neighbours or anyone in your community when you most need us.As we mark our eighth birthday on May , we are asking the people of Scotland,they can, to support us into the future. Any donation, however small, to celebrate our anniversary will help to save a le – just like the numerous lives we have already saved over almost , missions.SCAA vows to continue to transform emergency care in Scotland, particularly to our rural and island communities, with your support. Thank you.As a coalition of leading providers of care and support to vulnerable children and young people, we congratulate all MSPs on their election and welcome the consensus there is between the major political parties to tackle the growing mental health crisis in our young people.We have for some time raised concerns over a potential lost generation of vulnerable children and young people, whose mental health is being impacted even further by the Covid- pandemic.There have been dramatically increased waiting times for mental health treatment during lockdown.In December , for example,  per cent of children and young people had been waiting more than a year for specialist treatment, compared with . per cent in , a truly frightening statistic.A commitment by MSPs to focus on mental health, increasing investment in support services and intervention strategies, must be a priority for this parliament, giving our young people the care and support they need, when they need it.The frightening statistics on the deteriorating mental health of many young people presents a compelling case for a radical new plan for our struggling mental health services and for a national crusade to address what is a mental health pandemic, underpinned by considerably greater resourcing.This is a crisis we can overcome, but it will require a similar energy and commitment to that demonstrated for Covid-we are to achieve this and prevent many young people giving up on their futures.At sight loss charity RNIB Scotland, we are concerned the Covid- crisis might have impacted on people who are blind and partially sighted, many of whom are older.We would like to highlight the emotional reassurance and practical help we offer during the coronavirus lockdown and its aftermath.Covid has eclipsed all other health news in the past year but  people still start to lose their sight in Scotland every week. Add to that stress over Covid and the lockdowns and there could be more people needing support and reassurance.Our Need to Talk telephone counselling service remains available in Argyll and Bute and the Western Highlands for anyone diagnosed with sight loss, as well as families, friends and carers.Losing your sight can be devastating news to take in. But our trained helpers can support you in coming to terms with your condition and finding the way forward.The uncertainty during the Covid lockdown over access to basic shopping and medication, a lack of information in accessible formats, the social isolation, the barriers to being guided because of social distancing # these have all added to and compounded the mental and emotional stress people are experiencing.But we want people with sight loss to know they are not alone and that help is available.To contact the Need to Talk service, phone the RNIB Helpline on    or email needtotalk@rnib.org.uk

Thank you for supporting us during this incredibly challenging time.With the evenings getting longer and brighter, you can use your garden or patio as a great extension to your home, and just sit back and relax.It is at this time of year that lawns need to be mowed more frequently so here are some key pointers on getting that perfect cared-for look.Mow at least once a week and raise the mower blades when it is very hot weather.Don#t mow when grass is wet or during a drought and don#t collect your clippings during dry spells as this helps to conserve moisture.Keep watering throughout the summer unless there is a water shortage and repair bare patches with turf or re-seeding.This is also the month to ensure that all your plants are adequately fed, particularly those in baskets and tubs.Plants benefit from a regular feeding programme as they are growing vigorously and need their nutrition levels to be kept up.Slow-release granules are a good idea for pots and baskets because they last for about six months and release food as it is required into the compost.Not often thought of as a container plant, but an excellent option for small gardens, is a rose.A simple solution for June is to create an instant rose garden that you can enjoy throughout the summer.Just buy a selection of dferent sized pots, plant them with a ieties of roses and then place them together in a group.There is a rose for every garden situation. and .Earlier in the week, Belle set up a course record of .Both finalists are in the Scottish team to play in the European championships at Granton, Yorkshire, from June  to July .Two local fishing Thank you for supporting us during this incredibly challenging time.On May , you printed a letter from Ian Mitchell in which he claimed he did not receive any reply to an email he had sent me asking questions about Liberal Democrat policies.I replied to Mr Mitchell three hours and  minutes after receiving his email. Mr Mitchell acknowledged receipt of these answers.I was alarmed and saddened by the headline #Failing# school is #betraying# pupils and the community# in last week#s Courier.Coming from a retired Campbeltown Grammar Schoolteacher, it is hard to believe that someone who has worked in the profession could have such criticism for his her fellow colleagues.Although clearly passionate about the future of CGS, perhaps retirement has helped this inidual forget what a challenging job all school staff face.It is commonly known that CGS has not had its troubles to seek in recent years with major staff shortages due to ill health and other unforeseen circumstances.The league tables do not make good reading but, on their own, I don#t think they reflect the efforts of the staff.It is a well known fact that you can take a horse to water but you cannot make it drink. Is the behaviour of pupils the greatest barrier to success Despite the efforts of teachers to discipline the pupils, there are few deterrents for the offenders, especially where the pupil is aware that,they ask, the parent will fight their corner instead of backing the school.The responsibility of teaching our children to behave and respect others needs to be instilled from early years by us all and not just when the child reaches CGS.Maybe the retired teacher should offer his her skills and visit CGS and see the problems that all staff are facing It is time for the community to pull together and support our school and encourage our children to believe that a good education is very achievable in CGS.Recently, an investigation by the Herald newspaper uncovered that #just over half of Scotland#s leline ferry network is operating outwith its working le expectancy#, with  vessels out of  in operation over  years old.Despite the huge challenges created by the Covid- pandemic that our hard-working ferry crews have to deal with,  residents rightly expect a high quality ferry service that runs on time and has enough space to ensure they can travel to and from the islands, businesses can transport goods to the mainland and tourists can visit our islands to boost the economy.Unfortunately, cancellations and delays continue to plague routes. I have been working closely with residents, our community councils and other parties to find long-term solutions.This pressing matter simply can#t be left on the backburner.The  National Lottery Awards are now open for entries.Once again, the annual search for the UK#s favourite National Lottery-funded people and projects will recognise those iniduals and organisations who have made an extraordinary impact in their community – especially during these unprecedent times.National Lottery players raise £ million every week for good causes and we know this money is being used in amazing and inspiring ways.As part of The National Lottery Awards, we want to celebrate those whose selfless dedication and fantastic work makes such a dference in villages, towns and cities across the country.Encompassing all areas of National Lottery funding, you nominate local legends and hometown heroes in the following categories: culture, arts and film, community charity, heritage and sport.In addition, there will be a young hero award for someone under the age of .Groups or organisations are eligible to enter The National Lottery Project of the Year category, where shortlisted finalists will face a public vote later in the year.All award winners will receive an iconic National Lottery Awards trophy and £, for their organisation.Nominations can be made by completing an entry form on our website at www.lotterygoodcauses.org.uk awards.All nominees must have been funded by The National Lottery or be associated with a National Lottery funded project. Entries must be received by midnight on June .Now, as we approach summer with hopefully fewer restrictions, we can start to make plans about how we will spend time with family and friends.Following the challenging year we have experienced, we could all do with a bit more play in our lives. Play is a hugely important part of childhood and has a whole host of benefits, including improving physical and mental health and wellbeing.Throughout this pandemic, children have had to deal with so many dficult challenges some having to stay in unsafe homes and many living with families who are struggling with health worries and financial issues.Children have told Childline that they have struggled to cope and their mental health has suffered as a result.It doesn#t matter how people choose to play this Childhood Day , whether it#s organising a sponsored kickabout in the park, a game of cards, a musical get-together or an online gaming tournament, we just want as many as possible playing and raising money to help us keep children safe.We look forward to hearing how your readers plan to support the NSPCC and children across Scotland this Childhood Day.To find out more and download a fundraising pack, visit www.nspcc.org.uk childhoodday or search online for NSPCC Childhood Day.

Thank you for supporting us during this incredibly challenging time.With one million copies of the DCI Daley series sold across all formats, Denzil is now reaching out with a new voice and in a new direction.Fans of the television shows The Sopranos and Gangs of London are likely to enjoy Meyrick#s new novel, Terms of Restitution, which will be published in hardback in September.While the DCI Daley novels are set in Kinloch, a fictional town based on Denzil#s native Campbeltown, Terms of Restitution is a completely new venture, revealing the darker side of human nature and taking readers to the dark streets of London and the Scottish town Paisley.Gangland boss Zander Finn is so sickened by the brutal murder of his son in a Paisley pub that he decides to change his le.Following the advice of his priest and mentor, he moves clandestinely to London and becomes an ambulance driver.But when his old second-in-command Malky Maloney tracks him down on a London street, Finn knows he must .Both his real family and his crime family face an existential threat from Albanian mobsters determined to take control of the Scottish underworld.Facing the forces of law and order under Detective Chief InspectorAmelia Langley and a mysterious Italian woman, Finn struggles for survival in a rollercoaster ride of brutality, tenderness, misplaced loyalties and the utterly unexpected.The path to redemption is a bumpy one, and it begins to look like Finn should have stayed in London.#I#m absolutely thrilled to bring readers something new,# said Denzil, now resident on Loch Lomondside. #I#m a huge fan of The Sopranos television show the mix of visceral crime, family le and bags of humour, I think, more accurately represents real le than unremittingly dark noir.#Thinking about that model, I#ve used my own approach in Terms of Restitution. Nobody lives a single-themed le, and I believe it#s really important,any authenticity is to be had, that characters inhabit as real and relatable a world as possible.#In Terms of Restitution, we see the stresses and strains of le on Zander Finn, as he struggles to come to terms with the pressure of his two families, his blood relatives, and his business family.#I#m also excited to unveil a new cast of characters, full of strong women like DCI Amelia Langley, and Maggie Finn, the formidable matriarch of both Zander#s families.#All told, I#m more than excited to let you spend time with the Finns in Terms of Restitution.#Is this a scintillating one-off  Or will it be the start of a new must-buy series  Denzil#s fans from Campbeltown to Canada will be thrilled to find out.And for those who can#t wait, his ninth DCI Daley novel, For Any Other Truth, will be published on June .

title: musselburgh-lollipop-man-john-mclay-praised-one-kind
story: Popular John McLay, , who mans a crossing at Pinkie Road, near Pinkie St Peterrsquos Primary School, goes the extra mile by wearing lsquocool characterrsquo socks and festive hats, turning into Santa at Christmas and buying a bunch of flowers each Friday to give to someone in the street in a bid to brighten up their day.Parent Kirsty Clark, who runs the after-school club, said: ldquoHe really is one of a kind, a truly caring and lovely man. He is always smiling even in the worst of weather. He takes the time to learn the childrenrsquos names and chats away to everyone.She explained that Mr McLay, of Goosegreen Avenue, Musselburgh, brings personal touches to the job like wearing ldquocool character socks that the children talk about all the way to school.At Christmas, he brings seasonal joy to everyone by wearing a dferent festive hat every day throughout December. He also grows a beard to play Santa at the after-school club but doesnrsquot fool the children, who know him so well.Mr McLay, who was brought up in Wallyford and has been a lollipop man for five years next month, said: ldquoIt is the best job Irsquove ever had.A sheet metal worker for Lothian Buses for  years, he took early retirement after caring for his late we, who was diagnosed with motor neurone disease.He said he was ldquoprivileged to work with the children and their parents.An East Lothian Council spokesperson said: ldquoWersquore delighted to hear the positive comments about John and how appreciated he is by the families.ldquoOur crossing patrol guides provide a familiar and friendly face for children and families at either end of the school day. The guides are a much-valued part of the school community and we know that they enjoy the interaction they have with families too. Itrsquos lovely to see the Pinkie St Peterrsquos parents recognising this.One parent said: ldquoWe have recently moved but every morning my son insists on walking the long way so he can cross lsquoJohnrsquos roadrsquo.Another commented: ldquoMy twins are obsessed with John. It was one of the first names they were able to say.One said: ldquoMy kids just love him: the youngest is always so excited to see him and anytime we see him outside of the lsquolollipoprsquo role, he always takes the time to come and say hello.Another parent added: ldquoWersquove been here four years and he remembers each of the kidsrsquo birthdays. When my mum and dad visit from Fe, he always chats to my dad about the footie and,hersquos not seen them visit in a while, he will ask after them. Hersquos got a heart of gold.ldquoItrsquos not just in his job that hersquos so great, itrsquos outside in the community too, said another.ldquoHe saw us one night in Tesco looking a bit frazzled. As we were at the checkout, he came back with a bottle of Prosecco for me and said: lsquoHerersquos something to brighten your night.rsquo Too sweet!Another parent said: ldquoEvery Friday, John buys a bunch of flowers and gives them to a random person in the street in the hope it will brighten up their day.ldquoHe really is just such a genuinely nice person inside and out.The pupils also praised Mr McLay.Robbie said: ldquoJohn helps us to cross the road and makes me laugh, hersquos really funny.And Eli added: ldquoThe lollipop man is very fun and funny, he makes me smile in the morning.While Milo said: ldquoHersquos amazing and hersquos the best.Cathy added: ldquoJohn is cool and kind. I like his socks.

title: refurbishment-alterations-planned-cockenzie-primary-school
story: East Lothian Council is seeking permission to make alterations, including the demolition of a redundant chimney, at Cockenzie Primary School.The planning application, which is being considered by the local authorityrsquos planning department, outlines the work proposed.A spokeswoman for East Lothian Council anticipated that the work could be carried out during the school holidays.She said: ldquoSubject to planning approval, work will be carried out at Cockenzie Primary School over the summer holidays involving major external refurbishment.ldquoThis includes flat roofing works, rooflight and window replacement, installation of an external insulated render system and the demolition of a redundant chimney.ldquoIn addition, internal works include an electrical rewire, new lighting and suspended ceilings to be undertaken to five classrooms.ldquoThis is part of a rolling programme of primary school project works and maintenance.

title: new-owners-taking-drummohr-caravan-park
story: International real estate advisor Savills, on behalf of private clients, has completed the sale of Drummohr at Levenhall, Musselburgh, to employee-owned leisure, retail and distribution specialist WCF Ltd for an undisclosed amount.Jo Ritzema, managing director of WCF Ltd, said this was the companyrsquos first caravan, camping and glamping site in Scotland, with the nearest being a five-star facility at Herding Hill Farm near Hadrianrsquos Wall in Northumberland.She stressed that the company hoped to go on to increase its portfolio of camping and glamping sites in southern Scotland and the north of England.The site is developed to accommodate  luxury holiday letting lodges, seven of which have hot tubs,  touring caravans, tents and motorhomes, together with  glamping units.The site also includes a storage area for up to  touring caravans, a three-bedroom bungalow with hot tub, two amenity blocks and a shop.The .-acresite is situated in the formerly walled gardens of a monastery and was converted to a holiday park in . It has been owned and run by the same family since .Mrs Ritzema first visited Drummohr as a camper herself, saying it benefited from the draw of Edinburgh and the ldquobeautul coastline and countryside of East Lothian.She said that the company, which has its registered office at Brampton, near Carlisle, had started an external refurbishment programme at Drummohr involving painting and decorating, with further plans to ldquoupdate and upgrade the facilities such as lodges and glamping units.She said that the site had a large touring area for tents and caravans which would also be improved, with the amenity blocks, accommodating showers, toilets and laundry, refurbished. It was also planned to add an indoor area including a kitchen for campers.Mrs Ritzema added that, given the ldquosignicant growth in glamping, additional units would be provided subject to consultation and the necessary planning consents.She added that the seven staff members, one of them part-time, who worked at the site had been retained, with a recruitment process under way for a further three or four new employees.They either live on-site or in the local area, including Angie Purves, an East Lothian resident who has been promoted from office manager to take over the running of Drummohr.Mrs Ritzema said that everyone involved in the venture was ldquomadly excited by it all and added that a new website for the site would highlight local visitor attractions.Richard Prestwich, director in the leisure and trade team at Savills, said: ldquoHoliday parks have become exceptionally sought-after due to the growing trend for staycations. It is encouraging to witness new entrants, such as WCF, targeting the holiday parks market and competing with the existing multi-park owners that have traditionally dominated the marketplace.

title: josh-taylors-fiancee-danielle-murphy-ecstatic-win---hoping-start-wedding-planning
story: Danielle Murphy watched the fight from home in Haddington after Covid- restrictions prevented her from flying to Las Vegas.Josh, from Prestonpans, beat his American rival with a unanimous points victory to become the undisputed super lightweight world champion.: Josh Taylor crowned undisputed world championDanielle told the Courier: ldquoI am absolutely ecstatic about his win, he has made history."All the hard work, dedication and years that he has put into his craft have paid off.ldquoI was gutted not to fly over, there have been other times when he has gone away and we havenrsquot been able to be there but with the magnitude of this fight, everyone wanted to be there to support him, but we were all cheering him on and screaming for him at the television.Danielle said the Taylor family are excited to celebrate when the world champion touches down in Scotland today , but Covid- restrictions are making it dficult.She said: ldquoWe are having to play it by ear because it is hard to book anything."Normally we would go into a hall or celebrate in a pub but there are only so many people you can have in aand there is no way you could only pick  people to celebrate, so we arenrsquot doing that.ldquoWe are hoping to be able to get an open-top bus for him, but we need to seethe council will allow that.Danielle was disappointed by the lack of national televised coverage of the fight.She said: ldquoIt is absolutely shocking that the fight wasnrsquot broadcast on a bigger  for others to be able to watch.ldquoThe older generation do not have smartphones, so they were struggling to watch it when it was on because it was streamed through an app."Danielle said Josh was flying home on Tuesday for some well-deserved time off.The couple got engaged in Dubai last December.Danielle said: "Hopefully he can take some time off so we can get our wedding planned and chill for a while."

title: picture-gallery-duke-duchess-cambridge-visit-heavy-sound-cockenzie
story: William and Catherine, the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge, were in Cockenzie yesterday as part of their ongoing tour of Scotland.The couple were visiting Heavy Sound, which works with the Scottish Violence Reduction Unit , a joint project backed by the police and the Scottish Government which tries to tackle the root causes of violence.During the visit, the Duke and Duchess saw young people doing martial arts, music production and bicycle maintenance, organised by community organisation Heavy Sound, which is based at the Cockenzie Hub on Edinburgh Road.Manager Thilo Pfander persuaded Kate to try her hand at making some EDMand at first the Duchess received some encouragement from her husband, who said: "Yeah, drop a beat in the background."Kate did produce a bass-heavy track but added a piercing synth sound over the top.William laughed and said: "Whats that "It sounded like a cat... story: Proud residents gathered outside the Prestoungrange Gothenburg to welcome home their own Tartan Tornado after he beat his American rival Jose Ramirez in Las Vegas this weekend.Josh was crowned undisputed super lightweight champion of the world on Saturday after a stunning unanimous points victory.: Josh Taylor crowned undisputed super lightweight champion of the worldDedicated fans braved the cold and rain to catch a glimpse of the world champion as he arrived home.Josh, accompanied by his fianceacutee Danielle Murphy, slowed his car to soak in the adulation of the crowd that had gathered outside his local pub.One of the first to greet the heroic boxer was his dad, James .Diane Taylor, Joshs mum, said she was overwhelmed seeing her son again as he ed home from his history-making win.She added: "I feel absolutely amazing."The energy of him driving through was amazing because I was panicking there wasnt going to be anybody here because of a mix-up with the flights and everything, but when I saw everybody I was so pleased, it is brilliant."The crowd erupted into cheers and chants as the champion drove down High Street at pm.Lara Connerton and Kenny Ainslie came out to celebrate Joshs arrivalOne resident, Lara Connerton, said: "I am super proud, it is absolutely amazing."He stopped and spoke to everyone and he took photos with the children in the streets."He is absolutely lovely, a top guy.""We are going to go and have a pint to celebrate."Another, Kenny Ainslie, said: "Its lovely seeing him, we are so proud."The Courier was live from Prestonpans when Josh arrived ndash watch a short video of his arrival here.

story: Carrie Williamson was with her son and daughter, Finlay and Bonnie Loftus, aged seven and five, and their bulldog Mable, when they saw the stone propped up against a fence by Prestoungrange Mining Museum, Prestonpans.Read More: Heros welcome for Josh Taylor as he arrives home in PrestonpansJosh, from Prestonpans, beat his American rival Jose Ramirez with a unanimous points victory to become the undisputed super lightweight world champion in Las Vegas on Saturday."The children were super excited to find it especially when they realised it was specially made for a world champion," said Carrie.The family, who live at Pinkie Braes, took a quick photo of the stone and put it back in its place for others to find and enjoy.Read More: Josh Taylors fiancee excited to plan wedding to the heroJosh, who ed to Scotland yesterday, was greeted with a herorsquos welcome as he passed through Prestonpans at pm.Supporters gathered outside the Prestongrange Gothenburg to cheer for the titleholder as he slowed his car to soak in the elated crowds.Read More: Josh Taylor crowned undisputed champion of the worldFans waved Scottish flags and signs on the High Street as Josh headed home to Haddington for some well-deserved rest.One sign read: lsquoHaud yir wheest Ramiz, your belts are coming tae the Pans.rsquoResidents from Northbank Road, Prestonpans, huddled together amid the cold on Saturday night to watch Joshrsquos fight on a projector.A banner on the street said: ldquoThis is my hometown, the place I was born in, no matter where I go itrsquos in my soul.ldquoMy feet may wander a thousand places, but my heart will lead me back home to Prestonpans.

title: lone-swan-finds-new-love-river-esk-musselburgh
story: Bonnie was taken to a new home on the River Esk when she abandoned her nest at Figgate Park, Portobello, after losing her partner Clyde.It appeared he had been in a fight with another male swanand had to be put to sleep.Sarah Auldsmith, Scottish SPCA senior animal rescue officer, said: ldquoWe were contacted back in April about an injured swan at Figgate Park.ldquoIt appeared a resident male swan, Clyde, had been in a fight with another male, resulting in a leg injury that made him unable to walk.ldquoClyde had also had bad arthritis for a number of years, which had been slowly getting worse.ldquoThis, coupled with him now being completely unable to stand, meant that he would not recover and the dficult decision was made to put him to sleep to end his suffering.She explained that Bonnie abandoned her nest about a month after losing Clyde.ldquoShe had been doing her best to incubate them but without her partner, and with her constantly being attacked by the new male, the eggs were unfortunately not viable, said Sarah.ldquoBonnie was moved to Musselburgh a couple of weeks ago and seems to be getting on well in her new environment.ldquoWe havenrsquot heardshersquos found a new mate yet but this is certainly a possibility as swans will often take up with another partner after their previous one has passed away.ldquoWhen she moved, Bonnie left her eggs in the nest and they have most likely been predated on since then.Photographer Angus Bathgate, from Wallyford, captured Bonnie on camera enjoying her new le on the Esk and it is thought she may have even have found love again, after being snapped with a new admirer.Mr Bathgate said that during a visit to the Esk, he was told by someone who was involved with the welfare of the swans that Bonnie could be singled out by the identication number on her tag.He added: ldquoIt made my day when Bonnie and her new mate chose to show their bonding together, which I captured on camera.Sarah appealed to the public: ldquoIf you discover any injured wildle, please contact our helpline on   .

title: heavy-sound-founder-says-dad-joke-duke-duchess-cambridge-bombed-visit
story: Jordan Butler met the royal couple at its premises in Cockenzie Business Hub as they learned about Heavy Soundrsquos work and its partnership with the Scottish Violence Reduction Unit .The Duke and Duchess of Cambridge during their visit. All images: Andy Buchanan PA WireArriving at .pm, the couple, known as the Earl and Countess of Strathearn when in Scotland, squeezed a lot into their hour-and--minute visit.Heavy Sound, which moved from Tranent to Cockenzie last July, was the only place the couple visited in the hub in what is thought to be their first official visit to East Lothian.The Duchess tried mixing a dance music track alongside Jordan and music services manager Thilo Pfander but received a scathing review from her husband.: Picture gallery of Duke and Duchess of Cambridge visiting Heavy Sound in CockenzieDespite her insisting the track be deleted, Jordan said it had been saved and was waiting to hear what he could do with it, joking of a pending release.He added that the track was not as bad as the Duke made out and he enjoyed listening to it.But his ldquodad joke to the duo of getting royalties from the song should it be released did not go down as well as he thought it would, he recalled.William and Catherine also visited Heavy Soundrsquos community reach and inclusion bus , which is kitted out with recording equipment, IT and office equipment, a kitchen and hairdressing space.Jordan said the royals took a great interest in the project, discussed how it came about and the work it does.He added: ldquoOn board the bus they had a big interest in mental health.ldquoThey also had in-depth knowledge of childhood trauma and work with early years it is obviously something they know about and have a lot of knowledge in.Heavy Sound partners with vulnerable, disadvantaged and disengaged young people using music and sport.About  per cent of the young people have care experience and or complex childhood trauma. It works with  young people and  adults.Heavy Sound is in partnership with the SVRU, which helped make the CRIB possible alongside support from the Scottish Prison Service and STV Childrenrsquos Appeal.During the pandemic, the CRIB became an lsquoalternative classroomrsquo, offering a safe place for the children of key workers and vulnerable children. It also distributed , lunches during the first lockdown and , in the second.The royal couple also watched the Thai boxing group and mixed martial arts programme lsquoFight Like A Girlrsquo."We tried our best to get them [the royal couple] involved in Thai boxing and hitting some of the pads but they were more interested in speaking to the young people, said Jordan.ldquoKate did go on the mat with her high heels on, which is a big no-no, but you can make exceptions for certain people!William declined the invitation, saying he did not have the right equipment but that he used to box during his time in the army.Heavy Sound also works on mentoring and building skills and development, with William and Catherine also visiting Heavy Soundrsquos bike maintenance facility.The visit meant a lot to Jordan, who was homeless himself from the age of  to  and suffered with substance misuse as a result. Music was how he expressed himself, which is one reason why Heavy Sound has such a focus on it and ldquobuilding relationships and more alternative and positive forms of expression.He added: ldquoWe are able to offer our young people as many opportunities for positive engagement as possible and show them that through building relationships and engaging, they can get opportunities.Jordan told the story of one girl who suffers from social anxiety ndash she not only made it through the door on the day of the visit but spoke to the royal couple and showed off her artwork in an experience that Jordan said ldquowill stay with her for the rest of her le.On the Duke and Duchess, he said: ldquoThey are lovely and really down to earth. I felt incredibly relaxed."But it was so surreal at the same time. It did become normal pretty quickly, though.

title: newhailes-house-musselburgh-reopens-brand-new-visitor-attractions
story: The Palladian Villa, which boasts original furnishings and possessions from more than  years of inhabitants, has reopened with brand new visitor attractions.The National Trust for Scotland property has undergone restoration work to welcome visitors again after a sprinkler system mal and a moth infestation saw it close in February .The conservation charity has introduced a brand new visitor experience inside the house, with catering facilities available on the estate.Visitors can enjoy Weehailes Playpark and a new takeaway ice cream parlour and coffee shop, The Dairy.The dairy premises once provided milk, cream and butter for all those who lived and worked on the estate.The team at Newhailes has developed three new visitor tours, one of which can now be pre-booked at www.nts.org.ukThe first tour explores the last  years of le at Newhailes and the trustrsquos role in saving the house and estate.The second tour sheds further light on the property, telling the tales behind the art collections and objects in the house.The final tour is targeted at families and explores the home through storytelling it is suitable for those with young children.Claire Grant, operations manager for Edinburgh, said: ldquoWersquove been taking steps to revitalise Newhailes since before  and plans were further delayed when the pandemic hit.ldquoWe wanted to create a new experience that the local community could enjoy, in addition to offering a good-quality food and drinks experience.ldquoWersquore really excited to be welcoming visitors back to Newhailes House after what has been a very long period of closure and we hope they enjoy some of our new additions, like our Dairy and Stables Cafe.ldquoSo many people love this place, and we are really pleased to be able to welcome visitors from near and far back once again.ldquoAll of our properties across Edinburgh and the Lothians have been making visits as safe as possible."Pre-booking is in place at a few sites and there are smaller groups for house tours."She said that visitors should book their slot at Newhailes in advance to avoid any disappointment.Newhailes House is open to the public for tours from title: uk-australia-trade-deal-likened-highland-clearances-snp-accused-isolationism
story: Kenny MacAskill challenged Greg Hands, UK trade minister, over the plans in the Commons this afternoon, saying the Tories ldquodonrsquot even care about Scottish sheep let alone crofters and farmers.The trade deal has raised concerns with farmers across the UK, who are worried that cheap imports of beef and lamb could see the demand for their home-grown produce dwindle.Others say they are worried about inferior products, such as hormone-injected beef coming to the UKs supermarkets - a claim the Government denies and says hormone-injected beef would never be allowed to be imported to the country.Mr MacAskill, Alba MP for East Lothian said: ldquoOver  years ago the Highland Clearances saw people shamefully replaced by sheep for landlord profits.ldquoNow this trade deal threatens to supplant those sheep with cheap imports for Tory dogma.Mr Hands replied that the production costs in the Asian markets were ldquotwice what they are in the UK adding: ldquo[This] makes it very competitive for Australia to sell into for example, markets like Japan, markets like Korea, where the domestic production price of beef is twice that in the UK.He added that the Australian lamb quota into the UK was ldquonot even fully used at the moment.Drew Hendry, the SNP MP for Inverness, Nairn, Badenoch and Strathspey, cited warnings from the National Farmersrsquo UnionScotland and England, saying they would struggle to competetarf-free access was granted to Australian beef and lamb exporters.Mr Hendry said the government was ldquosimply not listening to those at the sharp end and quoted NFU Scotland president Martin Kennedy, who said: ldquoOur seafood industry has already been hit hard by Brexit and now Scottish farming is next to be sacriced. Once again its Scotlands key industries which will bear the brunt of a Tory Brexit people here didnt vote for.Mr Hendry continued: ldquoNFU England warned ministers that they would struggle to compete of zero-tarfs trade on lamb or beef went ahead and the RSPCA have warned that tarf free access for Australia would betray the public, farmers, and the animals. These are just some of the warnings to government from those affected, not from politicians.ldquoWill the minister rule out tarf-free access for Australian agricultural produce However Mr Hands hit back, accusing the SNP of being ldquoisolationist and said Mr Hendry had ldquoserious questions to answer.He said: ldquoNever in  years has the SNP supported any trade deal done by either the UK, or even by the EU, even though key sectors of the Scottish economy like whiskey, like apparel, like fisheries, are dependent on trade.ldquoThey voted for no-deal Brexit, they voted against deals with our friends like Canada, Korea and South Africa. They didnt support deals with Japan or Singapore.ldquoI dont think that whatever assurances I have given you today or whatever turns out to actually be in the deal would make him and the SNP support this deal.ldquoWhen it comes to trade Mr Speaker, the SNP are isolationist and against the best interests of Scotland. ldquoPatricia Gibson, SNP MP also challenged Mr Hands, asking him why farmers could not understand ldquohow fabulous the UKrsquos deal was and adding: ldquoCould it be the case that this government is being disingenuous about the impact this deal will have on your farmers The minister said that Scotland would ldquobenefit from this deal very strongly overall.

title: crackdown-long-stay-parking-three-car-parks-among-new-waiting-restrictions-introduced
story: A meeting of the councilrsquos cabinet this week approved plans to limit waiting times at two Tranent car parks and one in Dunbar to just  minutes.The minority Labour administration was told that a car park on Abbeylands in Dunbar had been ldquoconstructed to assist with visitors accessing and utilising the High Street businesses however, it ldquois being used primarily as a long stay.They were asked to approve a bid to introduce a -minute waiting restriction at the car park, as well as Lindores car park in Tranent, which currently has a temporary restriction under the Safer Spaces project, and a section of car park across from Tranent Medical Practice.Councillors were told that patients had complained about being unable to park for appointments because it was always Musselburghrsquos Harbour Road to adjoining Lochend Road North.Additional speed restrictions are also being applied for under Traffic Regulation Ordersin West Barns, as well as a bid to stop up part of South Street in Belhaven and section of Newton Port, Haddington.The cabinet also approved a bid to introduce  new electric vehicle chargers at locations across the county, including  at Wallyfordrsquos park and ride facility.Following the approval of the plans to apply for new and amended TROs, Councillor Norman Hampshire, cabinet member for environment, said: ldquoEast Lothian Council has a responsibility to ensure local towns and villages have safe, accessible routes of travel that recognise the needs of a range of road users, pedestrians and businesses.ldquoAs the county title: zans-wildlife-diary-search-fantastic-fox
story: Pointy ears, russet but vivid red fur and a bushy tail make foxes unmistakable. These animals are easily adaptable to a iety of habitats: from meadows to woods to city streets. They can also survive on a wide range of food, such as small mammals, invertebrates and fruit, but they will take advantage of food discarded by people.Foxes are social animals who live in small groups that consist of a breeding male , a femaleand their cubs. Usually, the male and female bond for le but there will be occasions when the male may seek additional mating opportunities.Mating takes place in winter and this is when foxes are most vocal. If you happen to have a window open on a winter night and you hear a loud screaming noise that sounds like a high-pitched screech, it is most definitely a fox looking for a mate and fending off its rivals.In spring, females give birth to several cubs, which become fully self-sufficient by autumn when they leave their parents. Some cubs may decide to stay with their family and they will play a big part in raising the following yearrsquos litter.My adventure with foxes started not that long ago. I was always fascinated by them but never really happened to photograph them. Occasionally, I was lucky to catch a glimpse of a fox but usually it was late in the evening or in a dense woodland, where photo opportunities are low.At the beginning of this year, I promised myself that I would find a family of foxes and get some decent shots. You may not believe it, but I spent weeks studying Google Maps in search of the best spots in East Lothian that I would visit everything marked green or looking like an open space was in scope for investigation.As spring progressed, I started to become more and more lucky with foxes. I reached the point when I could see them almost each time I left the house. I have taken multiple images, but I was never happy with them, until one dayhellipIt was a sunny Saturday morning when I decided to go out and look for deer. I visited a local meadow and quickly spotted a roe deer buck which I decided to follow. I did not manage to take any photos of the deer because as soon as I rushed after him, a beautully coloured fox crossed my path. Every day thenceforth I was coming back home with more information about the fox that I found. Finally, I was rewarded with some lovely shots in the setting sun! This is something I was dreaming of for so long! These animals are fantastic and I have completely fallen for them .Now, with lockdown eased, I hope you will have a chance to spend more time outdoors and hopefully see some lovely foxes. Evenyou donrsquot spot them on your walk, donrsquot give up! Look for some signs which may indicate of their presence: fox pooor their underground burrow .Scats are usually easily identiable as they are twisted and contain bits of fur and bones. They are deposited at prominent spots such as on footpaths, stumps, posts or rocks. The den is nothing  but a circular hollow in the groundyou are brave enough to lower yourself and snf it, you will smell a strong and unpleasant scent. Foxes secrete this smelly odour to mark their territories but it also helps to distinguish iniduals . They also have scent glands on their feet, so they mark their well-used trails as they walk ndash this is quite helpful to effectively navigate at night.If you would like to share your fox sightings with me or advise about good photography spots, please get in touch. I will also be delighted to chat anything wildle, so please do come up to say helloyou see me out and about with my camera.Speak to you next month!www.zanslenswww.facebook zanslenswww.instagram zans_lenswww zans_lens

title: plans-lodged-crematorium-near-musselburgh
story: East Lothian Council will now consider the project from the Westerleigh Group, a developer and operator of crematoria and cemeteries, with  facilities in England, Scotland and Wales.A single-storey crematorium, of around m internally, which would house a -seat chapel, is planned in the larger of two fields on the site.There would be a waiting room, accessible toilets, administration office, crematory, covered walkway and floral tribute area.Car parking providing  spaces, including six disabled accessible bays and an additional four spaces for staff parking, and memorial gardens are also planned.George Bell, regional manager for north and east from Westerleigh Group, said: "There is a pressing need for a crematorium in East Lothian."East Lothian does not have a crematorium of their own and their residents currently have to travel long journeys into Edinburgh, through busy roads, to access a crematorium."The area already has a large population base and this is going to grow further in the coming years, with some signicant new housing developments being planned."If our planning application is successful, this new crematorium will also serve the wider Edinburgh City region."We pride ourselves on creating and maintaining crematoria which are welcoming, attractive places for remembrance and reflection, and which are true assets to their local communities."The teams at all our crematoria have proudly earned a reputation for providing exceptional care and support to local people, enabling families to remember, mourn and celebrate the lives of their loved ones in a way that is uniquely personal, and we look forward to hopefully being able to bring that same high level of service to the people of East Lothian."Earlier this year, we conducted a public consultation exercise and were delighted to receive a positive response."The full planning application has now been submitted and we hope to receive a decision in early autumn."The site of the proposed development is around  acres, located north of the village of Old Craighall. It is located to the south of the slip road linking the eastbound A to the westbound A and these form the northern and eastern boundaries of the new crematorium. The western boundary is formed by Old Craighall Road and the southern boundary is formed by a minor road linking Old Craighall Road with the eastern part of Dalkeith Country Park.A planning statement, issued on behalf of the company by Holder Planning, said: "The application site is in a very accessible location. The A and the Edinburgh City Bypassconverge nearby to offer excellent levels of road access from a large surrounding catchment. The site can also be accessed via public transport."It added: "Signicant increases in population and death are projected for East Lothian, Midlothian and Edinburgh over the next  years, which will materially increase the demand for cremation services."Also highlighted were the supposed economic benefits:The planning statement concluded: "Westerleigh have undertaken a comprehensive public consultation exercise in advance of submitting the planning application, including meetings with the Old Craighall Residents Association and Musselburgh  Inveresk Community Council."There were no specic objections to the proposals, although understandably the residents of Old Craighall were keen to minimise any perceived negative impacts of the crematorium. Westerleigh have tried to respond to these points where possible."Kenny MacAskill, MP for East Lothian, said: "An expanding population and a growing elderly community mean facilities are under increasing pressure."Crematoria are things we sometimes prefer to avoid discussing but theyre essential and delays in accessing them can be distressing."Whether this site or development is appropriate is for planning officers and the planning council to decide but theres a growing need for one somewhere local."

title: tesco-trial-new-service-help-make-life-easier-customers
story: The supermarket chain is launching a new rapid delivery service which will mean it can deliver groceries to customers within an hour.The retail giant is initially trialling the Whoosh delivery service at one store and will then assess potential opportunities to expand the model.It said the one-hour service will be available for customers in selected postcodes around its Wolverhampton Willenhall Express store.The supermarket chain has seen soaring online growth during the pandemic but has so far refrained from following rivals into the on-demand grocery space.Sainsburyrsquos operates its own Chop Chop rapid delivery business, as well as services through Deliveroo and Uber Eats.Meanwhile, Waitrose recently scrapped its own Zoom rapid delivery business in favour of expanding its tie-up with Deliveroo.A raft of major grocery retailers, including Morrisons, Aldi and the Co-op, also use delivery operators such as Deliveroo and Uber Eats to reach customers.Tesco said customers will now be able to order on-demand via its app or Tesco, with products delivered by bike, moped or car, with a pound delivery fee.Chris Poad, online managing director at Tesco, said: ldquoCustomers are telling us that they would welcome the addition of a -minute delivery to their door option as part of our online grocery service.ldquoWersquoll use the pilot to understand how Whoosh could work best for both our customers and our colleagues.

title: dunbar-mums-super-effort-get-set-marathon-relay-run-groups-helped
story: Seven mums ndash and a dad ndash will cover a total of  miles this weekend in aid of Downrsquos Syndrome Scotland and Kindred.The parents met through ante-natal classes in Dunbar and are taking part in the Edinburgh Marathon Festival, held virtually due to coronavirus restrictions.Lisa Kitson, Libi Newell, Charlie Hardy and Ky Normand will form the lsquoSuper Mumsrsquo, with Catherine Devereux, Laura Bell, Sarah Callow and Jonathan Newell as the lsquoWonder Womenrsquo, with both teams taking part in the relay event.And another member of the ante-natal classes ndash Caroline Nelson ndash is providing the costumes for the runners, to ensure they look super as they complete the challenge.For Caroline, Catherine and Laura, the causes are close to their hearts. Carolinersquos son Harris and Laurarsquos son Sandy were both born with cerebral palsy, while Catherinersquos daughter Sophie has Downrsquos syndrome.Catherine, , said the two charities had both provided support.She said: ldquoOnce I was able to start looking into things, Downrsquos Syndrome Scotland were just able to provide me a lot of information, a lot of support and a lot of reassurance ndash just simply knowing they were on the end of a phoneI had any queries, be it what I need to be thinking about medically, what appointment we might be thinking or approaching coming up.It was through Downrsquos Syndrome Scotland that Catherine, who works in events, was pointed in the direction of Kindred, which supports parents of children with complex needs with advocacy, information and emotional support.Catherine added: ldquoI have been able to benefit from their counselling services, which have been a great help to me, as well as Laura.The mums all met through ante-natal classes held in Dunbar Medical Centre in the autumn of .Since their babies were born, each has kept in touch.Catherine said: ldquoWe were encouraged at the classes to share numbers and make our WhatsApp group, which has kept going since our children were born and they are now two to two-and-a-half.Together, the mums, who all live in Dunbar or previously lived in the town, are taking on the running challenge, with each lacing up their running shoes ndash and donning their costumes, with Jonathan vowing to pull on a skirtthey reach their fundraising target ndash to run four, six or eight miles.Catherine told the Courier running had proven beneficial not just physically but mentally as well.She said: ldquoI actually started doing Couch to k when my daughter was about eight weeks old.ldquoI had run before but had quite a long break from it.ldquoIt was quite a good thing for me to latch onto and I really love to run with some people as well because I had been doing it largely on my own. It is incredibly beneficial not just physically but mentally.Eddie McConnell, chief executive of Downrsquos Syndrome Scotland, wished the runners well.He said: ldquoWe are so grateful to the Dunbar Super Mums and Dunbar Wonder Women for choosing to support Downrsquos Syndrome Scotland.ldquoThe Edinburgh Marathon Relay is a huge challenge to undertake and their commitment in taking on this challenge to support our charity means a great deal to us.ldquoTheir fabulous support and the funds they have raised will help us continue to support families and people with Downrsquos syndrome reach their fullest potential.A spokeswoman for Kindred also wished each of the runners well.She said: ldquoKindred has a new dedicated four-person office based at the new Royal Hospital for Children and Young People. This is better located for East Lothian families than the old hospital, now many of the childrenrsquos services are in the same building so appointment times can be shorter.ldquoKindredrsquos hospital team offers families, emotional and practical support as well as being able to support them at clinical meetings, to understand complex medical information, so they can advocate on behalf of the family or simply help them best represent their childrsquos needs.To support the mums, go to uk.virginmoneygiving Team DunbarSuperMumsandDunbarWonderWomen

title: paul-mclennan-msp-column-saying-first-speech-holyrood
story: Irsquom fortunate to have been selected to speak early in this Parliament and Irsquom sharing the outline of my first speech, becoming your voice at Holyrood today .You expect me to deliver for you and, back in January, I promised that my priority would be protecting residentsrsquo wellbeing on our path through the pandemic recovery. My remarks will be addressing how to protect your services secure investment in existing and new facilities on which you depend and ensure that your longer-term needs are met.I stand by my promises and can report progress: the First Minister already specically identied East Lothian Community Hospital as one that would benefit from new spending on local access to healthcare.Boris Johnsonrsquos hard Brexit is damaging farming and tourism, our local food and drink industry and other businesses. As with the unseasonal weather, Brexit is outside our control in East Lothian. However, the SNPrsquos positive and pioneering vision of a green recovery is helping to underpin the countyrsquos sustainability and viability, with the Government delivering  per cent rates relief for retail, leisure, hospitality and aviation for this financial year, along with a rural entrepreneur fund to support businesses.There can be no recovery unless our children and young people flourish. Funds for summer activity schemes will benefit East Lothianrsquos communities locally and pound billion more will directly support teachersrsquo work on closing the deeply rooted attainment gap and the poverty it can perpetuate.Finally, Irsquove set up a new group of South of Scotland SNP MSPs to discuss strategic issues impacting across the region. One of these will be our share of , new houses: I know how strongly you feel about the inter-relationship between affordable housing, appropriate services, public transport and parking.My speech will demonstrate my focus on the Covid recovery in East Lothian, ensuring the county comes out of the pandemic with stronger public services and we can all look forward to a bright future.

title: musselburgh-north-berwick-swimming-pools-close-maintenance-work-completed
story: enjoyleisure welcomed back customers to North Berwick and Musselburgh swimming pools on May , following months of closure due to both the ongoing works and lockdown.The pools were both modernised with new floating floors and booms installed.When the facilities reopened, a maximum depth of . metres was in place and customers were told that more work was needed to make the new booms fully operational.The engineering contractors are toto each pool with the necessary components and materials, which have been custom designed and made for enjoyleisure, and complete the installation.In order to complete the works, specialist sub-contractor ing teams are also scheduled to be in each pool. As a result, both the North Berwick and Musselburgh venues will need to temporarily close.Musselburghs swimming pool will be closed between June  and , while in North Berwick the pool will be closed between June  and . The other facilities in each building will still be available.All of the other pools in East Lothian ndash in Dunbar, Haddington, Tranent and Prestonpans ndash will be open and available for use.Once the boom is fully operational, enjoyleisure will be able to provide iable pool depths for classes and swimming lessons, reinstate family tanks and increase the depth of the pool to provide access to the ing blocks during club sessions.Bill Axon, enjoyleisure chief executive, said: ldquoWe would like to once again express our sincere thanks for our customers patience and understanding during the upgrade of the pool facilities at Musselburgh and North Berwick.ldquoWe fully appreciate that a further interruption of swimming pool access will cause some frustration for our customers.ldquoHowever, both our maintenance partners, East Lothian Council and the engineering contractors are confident this final stage will resolve our outstanding snagging issues.ldquoI sincerely apologise for any disappointment and inconvenience caused.

title: east-lothian-peeps-past-may-24-28-1996-1971-1921
story: IT WAS the end of an era in North Berwick, reported the East Lothian Courier on May , .James Mitchell is set to retire after half-a-century in the motor trade which will mark the end of an era as a consultant.When he was , Jimmy as he is widely known, began his apprenticeship as a mechanic at Gilbertrsquos Garage.It was one of the countyrsquos most renowned garages at that time and had many
