Causeway Coast and Glens Borough Council will review remote meeting arrangements in the Autumn after making provision for remote meetings until then. The councils Corporate Policy and Resources Committee last week altered their standing orders to allow for remote meetings after the Stormont governments legislation expired earlier this month. Councillor Darryl Wilson suggested reviewing the changes in September with a view to councillors ing to the chamber, but said remote access could still be granted for council staff. “The pandemic is still here, and we will do what we can to keep staff and elected representatives safe,” he said. “I personally find the governance and democratic works best when all elected members are present here. googletag.cmd.push “I understand why they cant be at the minute, butthe opportunity arises in the future, I think they should be in here. “I dont think this applies to staff. Weve sat here where members of staff have sat awaiting their item coming up for two, three hours. “Those staff are maybe having to get childcare and its not good time management for them, or for the finances of the council with fuel and other associated costs.” The suggestion sparked a passionate response from Benbradagh councillor Kathleen McGurk, who said the council should take the opportunity to make local politics more inclusive. googletag.cmd.push “I think we are missing a major opportunity to embrace this moving forward,” she told the committee. “There seems to be resistance from some members, who continually look to move back to the old way we were working, with members back in the chamber. “We have been looking at ways of becoming a more inclusive organisation and bringing dferent people into politics why would we not extend the benefits of remote or hybrid meetings to members  “I am a young, working mother and its dficult to attend the chamber all the time. Remote meetings have meant I have been able to juggle home, working and political le much more easily.     “A review is fine, but why is the default position always how can we get everybody back into the chamber  “It really frustrates me to see the opposition to this opportunity to overhaul how we work and make politics a more inclusive environment for everybody.”  Alderman William Duddy said the optics of councillors being in the chamber was important. “We need to get back to an air of normality. Were elected to the chamber, were not elected to our kitchen tables,” he said. “Part of whats missing are the discussions in between, before and after the meetings that can help improve business within this council.” SDLP councillor Orla Beattie said members had forgotten about previous occasions when remote access to meetings may have been useful. “In the past weve had meetings cancelled because of weather,” she said. “Thats something we have to take into consideration sometimes its just safer to be working from home. Its an option we have to keep open.” Cllr James McCorkell concluded the discussion by saying the council should show leadership on getting things back to normality. “Anyone with health conditions, come September or October, will most certainly have had their second vaccine,” he said. “At this stage, we need to be looking at our mental health and getting out amongst people. There is a social aspect to this as well and I think we should show leadership on it.” The committee then voted to approve the motion to provide for remote or hybrid meetings, with a review to be held in September.  --XX DO NOT USEXX If you have a story or want to send a photo or video to us please contact the Derry Now editorial team on    for Derry City stories Or    for County Derry stories. Mid Ulster District Council is to form a working group on the issue of Irish unity after councillors backed a motion on the issue at last weeks full council meeting. A motion from Sinn Feacutein councillor John McNamee said the council had a duty to consult with rate payers on the issue of Irish reunication and suggested the council form a working group. The suggestions drew the ire of unionist councillors in the chamber, and a y debate on the pros and cons of a united Ireland followed. A parent of three children at a County Derry primary school earmarked for closure has hit out at a lack of communication from relevant authorities. Desertmartin Primary School will close its doors for a final time in August  after Education Minister Peter Weir approved plans for its closure in October . One parent, who has requested anonymity, said parents had sent two letters to the Department of Education , Education Authorityand the Derry Diocesan Board of Education , but had not received any reply. We have requested a meeting with the DDBOE and EA but to no avail. DE have been in limited contact with regards to this matter, they said. googletag.cmd.push There have been two letters sent by parents to all these parties raising questions and concerns regarding how proceedings have been handled and how very much out of the loop the parents have been. None of them have responded, which we feel is very unfair and just downright rude. Its not too much to ask for some answers, instead we get radio silence. We are very aware that the school cant be maintained as it stands at the minute and completely accept that it will be closing at the end of this term. We just cant fathom how the educational governing bodies and a religious organisation can be so evasive and feel that they are very under handed in their tactics. googletag.cmd.push We feel that their silence is in the hope thatthey dont respond to us by the end of June  then we will have to shut up and forget about it, that they wont have to answer our questions or concerns. The parent praised Desertmartin Primary School for the effect they have had on her children, one of whom has special educational needs. One of my children has special needs and will now be attending a new school. The progress my child has made since attending Desertmartin has been extraordinary, the staff have been unbelievable in how they have helped him.     He is reading and writing, something at one time I never thought hed be able to do, they have encouraged him, supported him and helped in so many ways that words could not describe how grateful I and my family are for them. It is just an absolute shame that in its final weeks of being open, the organisations involved at a higher level couldnt be a bit more open and honest with the families and people involved in the day to day of the school. It is a disgrace that these kinds of small rural schools wont be kept open due to financial reasons, when in so many cases the benefits of these smaller schools for so many children by far outweighs any amount of money. Last year, the Department of Education said all evidence had been taken into account regarding the decision to close the school. On  October , Education Minister Peter Weir approved the Development Proposalfor Desertmartin Primary School to discontinue with effectfrom  August at the latest, said a DE spokesperson. In reaching his decision the Minister gave careful consideration to the full range of evidence presented including all comments received during the statutory objection period and any pertinent statutory duties. The court heard police had responded to reports of a vehicle driving erratically and colliding with the central reservation on the road between Randalstown and Toome. Police located Stojanowskis vehicle two hours later on Aughrim Road, with the defendant sitting in the back seat, wearing an orange high-visibility vest and holding the car keys in his right hand. Officers detected the smell of alcohol, noted Stojanowskis eyes were glazed. A half-empty bottle of whiskey was also located in the passenger footwell of the car. googletag.cmd.push When questioned by police, the defendant said his we had been driving, and when police checks revealed this to be , he said maybe a friend had been driving the vehicle. After being subject to a road side breath test, Stojanowski said he had not been drinking while driving the car, that he had had a drink after stopping the car, and that he had been fishing. On December , police observed the defendants car swerving from the kerb to the hard shoulder and braking unnecessarily on the Moneymore Road, Magherafelt. After turning into Piney Hill, Magherafelt, police stopped the car and arrested Stojanowski again after smelling alcohol in the vehicle. He subsequently failed a breath test. googletag.cmd.push Defence for Stojanowski said he had been drinking at a friends house and did not think the alcohol would have an effect on his driving. Judge Mullan expressed concern that the defendant had been stopped for a similar offence within a month of the first incident occurring. She disqualied Stojanowski from driving for a period of two years, fined him pound for being in charge with excess alcohol in his breath and pound for driving with excess alcohol in his breath. title: ‘Wee Joe’ honoured for commitment to Ballynahinch
story: FOR the first fty years of Ballynahinch Rugby Club one name was synonymous with the club, a constant presence as they established themselves on the rugby landscape.That name was Joseph Kirkpatrick Carlisle mdash lsquoWee Joersquo to everyone who knows him in rugby circles in Ulster, Ireland and all over the world.He is a founder member of the club and fulfilled the role of first XV captain, match secretary, chairman, groundsman and tour manager, as well as having the honourable distinction of being the only man to have served twice as president.He was an ever-present on the club council and served as club representative to the Ulster Branch for  years until .These bare facts hide the colossal influence of Joe in the early years of the club as he drove it on from very humble beginnings in  to a much sought-after Townsrsquo Cup triumph in .Despite his diminutive stature, Joe was a wing forward on that team and was known for his relentless training regime. His -year playing career ended on the Evergreens in the early s.Joersquos role as match secretary for twenty years was absolutely crucial given his unique ability to dig out players when all seemed lost, recruiting players at Down High on Saturday mornings to fulfil fixtures later that day.Complete strangers would often turn up for second  matches in the early days saying that Joe had instructed them to turn up and play.Despite his tireless work on behalf of the club, Joersquos greatest pleasure throughout his rugby le has been the friends he has made along the way.A keen tourist, he has travelled the world to follow rugby and even took in some of the Lions fixtures in South Africa in .He was tour manager on the legendary  Ballynahinch tour of Canada, as well as partaking in a few trips away with the Evergreens.When promotion to the All-Ireland League was secured in , Joe was a regular spectator at games all over the country and could be seen at every first XV home fixture in his familiar spot on the m line until very recently.The flat cap, long navy Adidas coat, familiar cough and half pint of Harp should conjure up an image of Joe to everyone who knows him, and to countless others who have passed through the Ballynahinch club in recent years not knowing the huge influence he has had on their rugby.Joe is the recipient of the coveted Spence Cup this season. He is truly deserving of this award and it is le-affirming to see that friendships gained through team sports run deep as Sam Robinson, himself a Spence Cup winner, acts as carer for Joe as his health deteriorates.Rugby it seems, is giving something back to one of itrsquos finest local servants.On behalf of the Spence family, Emma Rice commened: ldquoThe Spence Cup is given to a member who shows an example of commitment to the rugby club. Joe Carlislersquos service to the club in time and deed epitomises this.ldquoA society grows great when old men plant trees whose shade they know they will never sit in. We are often guilty of not noticing a tree that gives the shade we sit under, she continued.ldquoPlayers of today may no longer see as much of that familiar face on the m line at Ballymacarn Park, but they will see the roots, the structure, the shade and benefit from what wee Joe once planted. Thank you and congratulations, Joe..prettyPhoto

title: Business owners join forces in their love of baking
story: THEY became virtual supporters of each otherrsquos business during lockdown mdash now two women bakers are working together to raise money for dementia research.Ciara Van Vogt, the owner of Margaretrsquos Cottage BB in Ardglass and Sharon Campbell from Mrs Crsquos Home Kitchen in Dundrum, have raised pound, so far for the Alzheimerrsquos Society from an online bake sale.They supported each otherrsquos business efforts through lockdown last year by connecting on social media but did not meet in person until March.When they did, the two ladies struck up an immediate friendship and decided to put their skills together and collaborate on a project.Sharon said: ldquoDuring lockdown charities have really suffered and there are many worthy causes out there, we both agreed it was hard to support just one.ldquoBoth businesses support their own inidual local charities and will continue to do, but we chose to support an Alzheimerrsquos charity because we both know many people affected by this awful disease.Ciara is a carer for her elderly mother, Mrs Eithne Fitzsimons, who was diagnosed with Alzheimerrsquos disease four years ago.ldquoI lose a bit of Mum every week, and sometimes Mum doesnrsquot know who I am, said Ciara.ldquoLockdown has stopped support groups and activities for people with dementia. Itrsquos been very challenging for carers and their loved ones, and people often forget that carersrsquo lives are adversely affected too.ldquoImagine having a spouse or parent who no longer recognises you and who due to this awful disease you no longer recognise.One of the things that resonates with both women is the thought of any loved one losing all our precious memories.Ciara continued: ldquoResearch into the causes of, and treatment for dementia is critically important but not a priority for UK governments.ldquoWe would love to see this dreadful disease eradicated for future generations. We both have strong ties to Northern Ireland, being from here, although we both spent time living and working in England and Scotland before moving home to settle back in Co Down. Our mutual love of baking and cooking was how we met and became friends.The two bakers organised a virtual bake sale to raise money for dementia research.However they soon realised that due to geography not everyone could buy their fabulous baking, so they set up a JustGiving page to run alongside the bake sale.ldquoPlanning the challenges of a bake sale during lockdown was fun, so too was choosing some of our most popular products to sell to raise money, said Sharon.ldquoThe menu proved so popular. Within ten days we both realised we wouldnrsquot get much sleep as baking for Alzheimerrsquos became a top priority.Early mornings and late nights meant that customers received their sweet treats and funds are still being raised by the pair.If you want to check out their Just Giving page, details are: https:www.justgiving fundraising sharonandciarasbakesale and both ladies can be found on Facebook and Instagram..prettyPhoto

title: Campbell on form as Duns claim derby win
story: DUNDRUM firsts defeated derby rivals Downpatrick by  runs on Friday evening to continue their push for a semi-final spot in the T Shield.Dundrum travelled to the Strangford Road after their pitch was deemed unplayable after heavy rain with the home side winning the toss and, on a cold damp evening, chose to field first.Dundrum opened with Greg Hutley and Stuart Campbell while Downpatrick opened the bowling with Justin Rea and Marty Gartland.Dundrum got off to a fast start adding  for the first wicket inside the first six overs before Hutley was dismissed for  off the bowling of Gartland.Dundrumrsquos run rate began to halt as a result of the combination of good Downpatrick bowling and a slow outfield.Terry Hutley and Campbell added  for the next wicket before Dundrum lost four quick wickets in the form of Campbell , Hutley , James Martinand Joel Maguire .This left Dundrum  for five with Downpatrick on top as Ian Wright and Gavin McNerlin added  for the next wicket before another clump of wickets fell to leave Dundrum  for nine after  overs.McNerlin managed to get Dundrum to  for nine from their  overs as he finished on  not out.The pick of the Downpatrick bowlers was James Ferguson who finished with figures of  for  from his four overs and the game was very much in the balance heading into the second innings.Downpatrick opened with brothers Michael and Daniel Carson whilst Dundrum elected to open the bowling with Davy Glover and Daniel Kearsley.Similar to Dundrumrsquos innings, Downpatrick got off to a fast start, putting on  for the first wicket inside the first six overs.The Downpatrick men combined well and began running fluently between the wickets to put the pressure on the Dundrum bowlers.Daniel Carsonwas dismissed off the bowling of Davy Glover after a good catch by Andrew Foster in the dee, with Paul Linehan next to the crease to join Michael Carson.Linehan looked to be aggressive, hitting a big six to keep the pressure on Dundrum as the two batsmen took the score to  for  inside nine overs.However, Dundrum began to fight back through Campbell and McNerlin. The former dismissed both Carson and Linehan in the same over to swing the match back in favour for Dundrum.This started a Downpatrick collapse with the last eight wickets falling for only  runs. McNerlin finished with figures of  for  from four overs while Campbell finished with  for  from his four overs, completing a -run win for Dundrum.It was a fantastic fight back for Dundrum and Downpatrick will know they let the game get away from them.Dundrum would like to thank Downpatrick Cricket Club for hosting the game with the match ball sponsored by Aiden McCabe from AMC building.Dundrum -Downpatrick  all outT SHIELD.prettyPhoto

title: Despair for Down in second defeat
story: DOWN were second best to a Meath side who ran out comfortable winners by a margin of seven points at Armaghrsquos Athletic Grounds on Sunday.Down were forfeiting their home advantage as a result of breaching the GAArsquos Covid- regulations during lockdown and perhaps that, coupled with the torrid weather conditions, attributed to their performance.Paddy Tally signicantly reshuffled his starting line-up following their opening day defeat against Mayo in Castlebar.The Down manager made a total of five changes, with goalkeeper Marc Reid and captain Darren OrsquoHagan the most notable of them all.Meath began the sharper of the two sides, but Down could not fault lady luck as their opponents were reduced to  men following a Eoin Harkey black card.The red and black outfit failed to take advantage of their additional man as Meath began scoring points through Cathal Hickey, Mathew Costello and Andrew Colgan.Corey Quinn did manage to score two points before the quarter for the Mourne county, but he also failed to convert a goal scoring chance which set the tone for the afternoon.The game was not away from Down at this stage as Quinn added to his tally alongside scores from Paul Devlin and Ryan McElroy to trail by only two points at half-time.It was a reverse in roles for the second half, as this time it was Down player Jonny Flynn who was shown the black card, leaving his side down a man.Unlike Down, Meath took full advantage of the extra shirt on the pitch and Cillian OrsquoSullivan buried two goals just before and after the third quarter to put the contest out of sight.Referee Niall Cullen was kept busy with his cards, this time displaying a red to Downrsquos Gerard McGovern to close out a miserable afternoon for Tallyrsquos men.Down now travel to Mullingar this Sunday, where they face off against Westmeath at Cusack Park.Down: M Reid P Fegan, G McGovern, P Murdock, P Laverty, D OrsquoHagan, C Mooney, R McEvoy , J Flynn, J Guinness, B OrsquoHagan , L Kerr, D Guinness, C Quinn , P Devlin .Subs: C Doherty for J Guinness , P Branagan for Mooney , S McConville for Kerr , G Collins for D OrsquoHagan , C Gough for Flynn , C McCrickardfor B OrsquoHagan , D Savage for Quinn Meath: A Colgan , S Lavin, C McGill, C Hickey , E Harkin, S McEntee, D Keogan, B Menton, P Harnan, E Devine , B McMahon , M Costello , J Morris , T OrsquoReilly , C OrsquoSullivan .Subs: R Ryan for Harkin , J Wallace for OrsquoReilly , E Wallacefor Hickey , J Scully for McMahon , J Conlon for Morris , D Campion for OrsquoSullivan , G McCoy for McEntee Referee: Niall Cullen Down -Meath -NFL DIVISION A.prettyPhoto

title: Dozens walk in memory of Seaforde Special Olympian
story: UPWARDS of  people took part in a charity walk around Castlewellan Lake on Saturday in memory of Seaforde man Glenn McBride, who died  weeks ago.Glennwas a medalled Special Olympics competitor who enjoyed soccer and basketball, playing both to a high standard.He was a popular member of of Down Special Olympics Club in Downpatrick and Shimna Stars Special Olympics Club in Newcastle.Glenn won a soccer gold medal with Team Down at the Area Games in Belfast in  and was a member of the Ulster soccer team at the Ireland Games the following year. He won a basketball gold medal with Team Ulster at the Ireland Games in .His friend Harry Walsh organised the walk in aid of the Belfast Cancer Centre to honour Glennrsquos commitment to the people who looked after him so well when he was ill.While Glenn had originally wanted to host a charity football match, he suggested a sponsored walk instead as it would be more Covid-aware.He never got the chance to host the walk but Harry continued it with it in his memory.Harry described his friend as having ldquothe kindest heart and soul who was always considerate to others.ldquoHe was never judgemental, and his passing has shown what a fantastic inspirational friend he was to many, he wrote on Facebook.ldquoHis passing is a huge loss and has left a massive hole in the lives of his family, his friends, me personally and this world in general..prettyPhoto

title: From the pages of the Down Recorder%2C May 30%2C 2011
story: DOWNPATRICK mdash Down District could be in line for a multi-million pound investment package which has the potential to create several hundred new jobs.Private talks between a number of key players in the financial and construction industries have been taking place over the past number of months and a major announcement is expected shortly.The core of the talks focused on Downpatrickrsquos poundm business park and an investment package of several million pounds has been put together to unlock its huge potential.It has emerged that plans are at an advanced stage to build a number of purpose built units at a -acre site at the Belfast Road complex to entice major companies to set up businesses in the area.The plan is to have business units in place to ensure that when investors do express an interest in coming to the area, they can move in almost immediately.One of the key men involved in the talks is local councillor Harvey Bicker and he has no doubt the amount of finance which has been put together can pave the way for ldquountold opportunities in the area.He has been able to secure the support of major financial players who have already agreed with the IDB to build the so-called advance factories at the Downpatrick business park.It is understood one major company is already interested in relocating its business to the Belfast Road site and several others are also believed to have expressed an interest in the -acre complex.NEWCASTLE mdash A teacher at Shimna Integrated College in Newcastle has this week discovered she is in a class of her own.A favourite amongst pupils, work colleagues and parents, Karen Caulfield, head of maths at the college, has been shortlisted for the prestigious Teacher of the Year award.The Rostrevor woman had been secretly nominated by several teaching colleagues and by parents of her students.According to school principal Kevin Lambe, Mrs Caulfieldrsquos colleagues entered her for the award as they were so impressed by her leadership qualities, her ability to inspire students, her innovative work and her organisation of the schoolrsquos numeracy strategy.ldquoMrs Caulfield is a wonderful teacher and a real asset to our college. Her colleagues all say that she has a real gt for helping students have confidence in their own ability, he said.KILLYLEAGH mdash The charred remains of Killyleagh GAA club, gutted in a blaze in the early hours of Monday morning, are to be demolished.The fire completely engulfed the clubhouse at Wolfe Tone Park, and it has been decided by club and Down County Board officials to demolish the clubhouse instead of refurbishing it.The building has been lying vacant since last year after the Wolfe Tone Club encountered financial dficulties and its teams were withdrawn from the Down leagues.The blaze, which spelled the final fate of the building, took place in the early hours of Monday morning.Downpatrick fire crews were alerted shortly after am and on arrival at the scene had to call for assistance from Ballynahinch and Comber to help control the flames.It took firemen more than four hours to bring the fire under control and by am on Monday morning all that was left of the vacant building was a crumbling shell and an acrid smell of hot ash.BALLYNAHINCH mdash A Ballynahinch student is flying high after gaining his private pilotrsquos licence.After months of gruelling training Phillip Miskimminrsquos dream of piloting a plane for a prestigious airline and travelling the world is well within his reach.As most  year-olds hop into the seat of a car, Phillip is now able to jump into the cockpit of a light aircraft, but the ambitious high-flyer is not going to settle at that.He is determined to one day become a flight captain for a commercial airline, flying passengers to destinations across the globe.Phillip was trained for his private pilotrsquos licence at Aldergrove Airport and was funded by a scholarship which he won from the Guild of Air Pilots and Navigators.The successful teenager was also the winner of the John Landymore trophy which is awarded to the most outstanding scholarship winner.Currently an aeronautical engineering student at Queenrsquos University, the former pupil of St Patrickrsquos Grammar School in Downpatrick has the world at his feet.The young pilot has had a passion for flying since he was  and is thrilled that he can now actually fly an aircraft.KILLOUGH mdash Raised from the ashes by the local community, Killough Hall once again stands proudly in the heart of the village.Local people, young and old, flocked to the newly built youth and community centre at Palatine Square to celebrate itrsquos official opening on Friday, four years after an overnight fire left it completely gutted.In an admirable community drive local people have resurrected the building which had been part of the local village for generations.Well known author historian and Killough native, Dr Maurice Hayes, officially unveiled the new centre which will provide leisure facilities, further education courses and a social venue for all.Reminiscing about his childhood days when he used to go to the hall every Saturday afternoon for his ldquohated dance classes, a jovial Dr Hayes said it was wonderful that the hall has been restored.Mr Hayes said everyone who worked so hard to get the hall back on its feet have helped bring a new heart and le into the building and a new heart and le into Killough.STRANGFORD ndash Bank Holiday Monday was a busy day for local RNLI and Coastguard members, with two call-outs off the County Down coastline.The first incident took place at around .pm in Strangford Lough when a sailing dinghy, with three men onboard, capsized close to The Long Sheelagh rock.One of the men was rescued by a passing fishing vessel while the others were clinging to the boatrsquos hull when Portaferry leboat arrived. A Wessex helicopter from RAF Aldergrove joined the rescue and members of Portaferry Coastguard were called to assist.ldquoAll three casualties were winched to the helicopter and taken to shore close to Kircubbin Sailing Club. None of the men, who were wearing wet suits and le jackets, were seriously injured and it is believed adverse weather conditions caused the boat to overturn, said a Coastguard spokeswoman.As this incident was closing and the helicopter had just landed the casualties, Coastguards then received information that two young boys were being blown offshore in a small boat close to Ballyhornan.ldquoThe helicopter was re-tasked and itrsquos crew stood by with members of the Ardglass Coastguard unit, but the children, who were aged  and , were able to make it back to shore safely, she added.SAINTFIELD ndash Teenagers in Saintfield are being blamed for vandalising stone walls and blocking a river in the town.Concerned residents in Shrewsbury Dale have voiced their concern about what is happening and asked local councillor Robert Burgess to address the problem.Mr Burgess said residents and local farmers are becoming increasingly concerned at the behaviour of the teenagers and highlighted the importance of making them realise the error of their ways.He explained that over the past number of months, children have punched holes in local hedgerows to gain access to fields adjacent to the Shrews-bury Dale housing development.ldquoLivestock and horses have been in the fields concerned and we have to be thankful they did not escape as a result of the childrenrsquos action, Mr Burgess continued..prettyPhoto

title: New £50k play park at Downpatrick school
story: A DOWNPATRICK primary school has officially opened its new pound, playground and garden facilities.St Colmcillersquos Primary School in Glebetown Drive now has a new sensory garden called the Rainbow garden, an outdoor play park and a new welcome garden at the schoolrsquos front door.School principal Stephen Austin said the facilities were financed by pound, raised by the careful management of the school budget and pound, from the schoolrsquos Parents, Teachers and Friends Association .Planns were drawn up last June and the work by contractor, All Play Ballynahinch, began in January.Mr Austin explained: ldquoThe school is set on a spacious site with several large green areas.ldquoI wanted to maximise the learning potential of our school site to improve pupils holistic learning experiences, particularly within the areas of outdoor education, activity based and play based learning which are essential areas of the curriculum and so important in eliciting enthusiasm in learning and developing key skills in core areas such as literacy, numeracy, ICT and STEAM.ldquoI also wanted to enhance facilities for our wonderful children who deserve the best and who were disadvantaged by interruptions to their schooling in recent times due to the Covid pandemic. But also to strengthen school community and pride in our fantastic school.Mr Austin paid tribute to the schools PTFA for its fundraising, to the board of governors for support and a group of volunteers who worked on the welcome garden.ldquoThe team spirit that has been displayed throughout this project has been uplting and a reflection of the strong school community that exists within St Colmcilles Primary School, he said.ldquoThe board of governors have supported this project throughout and are committed to a cycle of continuous improvement of all aspects of the school, especially its facilities and resourcesHe continued: ldquoThe PTFA have fundraised relentlessly through organising ious raffles, draws, bingos and hampers. They have enjoyed amazing support from our parents and the whole school community who all have been very generous. So far, they have contributed pound, to the project which has allowed us to go the extra mile with more extensive resources and a very high spec finish in the ious areas.He said that the welcome garden was created almost exclusively by volunteers such as grandparent Stephen Vaughan, who built the planter boxes, the garden furniture was designed and constructed by brothers Lawrence and Gareth Blaney, the circular stone planter built by parent Fergus Rooney , grounds work was carried out by Pascal Magee and planting by Bill Carew. Plants and shrubs were provided at a discounted rate from Cunningham Flowers in Dundrum.The schoolrsquos head of outdoor education, Sean McReynolds, oversaw the project with building supervisors Brian Tweedie and Bill Carew, classroom assistant Ryan Craig and Gemma Vaughan, the schoolrsquos eco co-ordinator.Parent Roisin McKenna, who along with Andrea McMenamin, Natasha Shields and Rosaleen Cunlfe leads the PTFA committee, said that they had enjoyed ldquoamazing support from parents, the wider school community and local businesses.Roisin said: ldquoThe ethos of our PTFA is about "making memories" and this is always at the forefront of our fundraising. We wanted the money we raised to benefit every child in the school and therefore the school have all the children timetabled for outdoor learning everyday.ldquoThis makes our fundraising all worthwhile when you see happy children playing daily outdoors.The PTFA organised fundraising initiatives like bingo, raffles, hampers and draws which have allowed the school to further develop the footprint of the planned facilities for the children.The schoolrsquos Rainbow garden includes a tepee, a water wall for directing and controlling the flow of water, an activity table, a water and sand tray, outdoor shelter, sensory plants with a vivid colour or smell and plastic coated activity table where children can paint use sand and textiles to show their learning.Therersquos also an outdoor classroom which can hold up to  pupils and adults with bespoke seating and a blackboard with outdoor musical equipment.Itrsquos contained within ranch style fencing and is very popular with all the schoolrsquos pupils, particularly those within its learning support centres, many of whom have complex sensory needs.The new play park contains swings, slide, climbing tower, monkey bars, balance equipment, ropes, seesaws seating and planting areas.Children are timetabled at break and lunch times and for certain lessons throughout the day.An eye-catching circular stone planter has been filled with a iety of shrubs and trees in the new Welcome garden.Therersquos also a bespoke reading area overlooking four large rectangular sleeper planter boxes filled with beautul summer flowers, a solar powered water fountain, a bird bath and bird tables..prettyPhoto

title: Politicians gather to mark Northern Ireland centenary
story: CROSSGAR marked Northern Irelandrsquos centenary on Monday with a special event.A number of local politicians including South Down MLA Harry Harvey and Rowallane councillors Billy Walker, Terry Andrews, Robert Burgess and Kathryn Owen met in the village square with each holding a torch which symbolised what happened in Crossgar a century ago when the province was formed.On that occasion, a bonfire was lit in the square by local residents to celebrate the creation of Northern Ireland on election night of the new parliament.The local MP was Sir James Craig, the first Prime Minister of Northern Ireland who had personal ties to Crossgar and had been its Westminster MP since .To mark the national and local event, local politicians from all parties were invited to hold a flame in a triangular shape on Monday symbolising the fire that was lit on the birth of the country in .Cllr Walker said he was delighted to have been invited to Crossgar to take part in the special event to mark Northern Irelandrsquos th birthday..prettyPhoto

title: Tributes paid to Down Rec soccer legend Jim Connolly
story: JIM Connolly died on April  after a hard fought two year battle with illness.His passing was marked by a phenomenal level of tributes.Social media,work colleagues, team-mates and opponents alike expressed how well liked and respected he was in all walks of le.He was first and last a family man whether it was his brothers and sisters, Angie and his children or his beloved grandchildren.However Coot, as he was known, had another family which he held dear. He had been a vital cog in the Down Rec team which enjoyed great success in the late Seventies.But it was and remains the case that the Down Rec experience is defined by the enduring friendships which have stood the test of time.Coot grew up in Stream Street and the reason he knocked back opportunities to perform at levels his talent merited may well lie there.That part of Downpatrick had three working class housing developments, Ardpatrick and Russell Park with Stream Street and Ibrox Park in the middle.Ibrox was their playground, the place where Coot first kicked a football.He was a Stream Street kid and it seems he never wanted to be anything .When Jim Prior took him to Down Rec, it was a marriage made in heaven.In that dressing room you had another more senior Stream Street kid. Coot would have idolized Tony lsquoDartrsquo Curran in those days as he was the leader of the pack.Russell Park resident Barney Fitzsimmons was there too, a swashbuckling goalscorer who enjoyed something akin to Roy of the Rovers status at the time.Then you had the late great Paddy lsquoGeordyrsquo Galbraith, who combined a hard man reputation with a heart of gold.Peter Mulhall was another player he would have admired, a winner who proved the perfect centre back partner for the laid-back Coot.The total respect he had for them was accorded to all of us even though he was a better player than any of us. That was Coot Connolly.Prior realized that he needed to recruit from outside Downpatrick to fulfill his ambitions for the club and over a period of time he recruited players from Portaferry, Strangford, Ardglass, Dundrum, Crossgar, Saintfield, Killyleagh and Ballygowan.They were brought in for their ability but Jim couldnrsquot have known that the erse personalities therein would create the perfect storm in the dressing room.Neither could he have anticipated the level of support which flowed from those villages in the seasons to come.Dressing rooms are bastions of banter and slagging and with Dart jester-in chief, the group relished every minute they spent together.The five strong Portaferry contingent proved to be a vital ingredient, their earthy Ards humour and the opportunities their accents provided for slagging sealing their popularity.Jackie Leckey and Barney Ross brought another dimension willing as they were to join in the shenanigans on and off the pitch. Coot loved the craic and happily joined in the banter.However, he left the slagging to other less sensitive creatures of which there were plenty.A good example was the time I decided to get the footballers perm which was in vogue at the time. I should have known better.I got slaughtered, Dart declaring that I looked more like Shirley Temple than Kevin Keegan.Those were the days, as the saying goes, but happily there were plenty of good days ahead of us.We have had many reunions with Coot, an ever present and every one of them underlined the strength of the bond we enjoy so much.Sadly those reunions tend to be confined to wakes and funerals nowadays and the baby of our team has now joined Shane Breen, Paddy Galbraith and Marty Ross on the sidelines.Coot would have been the first to remind me that the Rec wasnrsquot only about the players.The one and only Charlie Oakes was highly influential in his role as assistant manager, while Austy Keating doubled as chairman and groundsman for many years.Joe Lyttle was our physio and his son Joea loyal player for years while my sister Tina was a committee member and a fanatical fan.They were all fully paid up members of the Rec family and we continue to mourn their loss.I would love to have name checked every single member of the Rec family in this piece but time and space didnrsquot allow. My apologies.The laughter which rang through Cootrsquos house during his wake was a fitting farewell for someone who loved to laugh.He was a very special human being. We will miss him forever. Rest in peace mate..prettyPhoto

story: As a subscriber, you are shown % lessThose ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local servicesThese adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityThe Royal Ulster Winter Fair enters its fourth decade next week as the st Winter Fair in association with Danske Bank takes place at the Eikon Exhibition Centre, at Balmoral Park, near Lisburn.Farmers from across Northern Ireland will be travelling to the showgrounds at the Maze for the one-day event on Thursday next, December .Regarded as the premier event in the national dairy calendar, it provides an opportunity for farmers, exhibitors and industry specialists while in the showring, there will be keen competition as quality livestock from Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland compete for the coveted title of Supreme Champion.Danske Bank have sponsored the event since its inception in  and John Henning, Head of Agricultural Relations at Danske Bank commented: ldquoOur sole sponsorship of the Winter Fair now enters a fourth decade - quite an achievement in an era where such long term business relationships arenrsquot as common place, as they once were ndash and we are very proud to have sponsored one of the biggest events in the agri-food calendar in Northern Ireland during this time.We value our close links with the Winter Fair and hope that our investment in the event - both financial and people - has contributed to the undoubted success of this major dairy showcase.ldquoOur support for the Winter Fair reflects a strong and ongoing commitment to the wider agri-food industry in Northern Ireland ndash both in terms of signicant lending to the sector and expertise of our dedicated Agribusiness team.ldquoItrsquos the event lsquowhere the dairy industry meetsrsquo each December and I have no doubt that this yearrsquos Winter Fair on December  will be another outstanding success - despite dficult times in the industry and ongoing uncertainty for dairy farmers.On the cusp of Christmas, visitors flock to the Winter Fair and observe the highest quality of livestock competing. This year the RUAS are delighted to welcome Paul Trapp, who is travelling from Wisconsin, USA, to judge. The event is also a great chance to interact with  dairy related trade exhibitors on the most relevant technological advances, dficulties and solutions in the industry. Rhonda Geary, Operations Director, RUAS said: ldquo saw the move of Winter Fair to our new purpose built exhibition venue, Eikon Exhibition Centre at Balmoral Park. The move has worked brilliantly and attracted one of the largest attendances to date. In preparation for the st Winter Fair we have increased the livestock accommodation and now have stalling, washing and milking facilities for  cattle. There is m of exhibition space and a full house of  trade stands. During the Winter Fair there is a busy Seminar Suite with talks presented every half hour from am until .pm.Dr. John Bailey from AFBI will speak about better phosphorous management, Bobby Irwin of United Feeds presents a paper on getting the lactation to the right start and Roberta Simmons of the YFCU and Barclay Bell, President of the UFU will speak about succession on farms.CAFRErsquos Martin Mulholland will be advising on feed efficiency this winter, making optimum use of grass silage while Christopher Osborne form the UFU will speak about dairy commodity markets and the prospects for .Dr. Sam Strain and Sharon Verner from the Animal Health and Welfare Northern Ireland will look at improved biosecurity and BVD while Jessica Sloss from Red Tractor, speaks about the farm assurance scheme.The live calf rearing demonstration will be making afor the  Show. Gorteade Cow Care owned by Barry OrsquoLoughlin will be displaying a fully ing calf igloo with veranda and Heatwave ad lib calf feeder.One of the innovative technological features at next weekrsquos Winter Fair will be the Northern Ireland launch of the CalfApp and Calf Cloud by Volac which won gold at Eurotier in Hannover. It gives information about changes in drinking pattern and fluid intakes and monitors calf health.The launch of the Winter Fair was held at Draynes Farm, near Lisburn, where Michael Drayne led a tour of agricultural journalists and industry representatives around his farm and milk bottling plant. The milk botting plant began when his father began with a horse and cart. Now the business has a fleet of vans distributing milk and dairy produces to customers in four counties. However their products are supplied to customers across Ireland through the Henderson Food Service and other companies.The borehole gives Draynes Farm a constant supply of water which is also useful to soften the mains water for washing.A KVA solar  plant has been installed on the roofs of some of the buildings.Draynes Farm processes m litres of milk per year and operates Monday to Friday with their own supply of . million litres of farm milk held over the weekend until the beginning of a new week. A total of  staff are employed in all departments.The Draynes Farm dairy herd uses three Lely Astronaut A milking robots. The cows visit the robots on average . times per day averaging  litres per day with some exceeding litres. title: penarth ramblers explore history nature walk
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityIt was girl power when ten female walkers joined Joy and sheepdog Bracken from Penarth and District Ramblers at Penarth clftop for an . mile walk, with no stiles only gates and which would see them experiencing the weather of all four seasons in one day. They set off on a socially distanced walk in lovely spring sunshine across the old pitch and putt course before joining part of the old railway line, now a walk and cycle way, and heading through a built up area Lavernock Road led them into Cosmeston Country Park.Past the eastern lake with its floating jetty where canoes can be safely launched and making their way through the eastern paddock with its carpet of pretty cowslips, open meadows led them towards Old Cogan Hall Farm, where they deviated into the churchyard of St Peterrsquos for morning break in glorious warm sunshine reminiscent of summer. Admiring the herring bone masonry which dates to Celtic and Saxon times and the ancient yew trees that could even pre-date this lovely old church, which allegedly is the oldest building in Penarth and hearing some of its long and interesting history, it fell into disrepair in the th century. By the th century the ruinous building was a cattle shelter until the latter part of the rsquos when the rd Marquis of Bute was persuaded to pay for its renovation.Mile Road built by the Bute family led them to the western paddock and through the sun-dappled Cogan Wood to re-enter fields where a footbridge led them across the Sully Brook for the short climb up to Home Farm, with its glorious views towards the eastern end of Barry and the surrounding farmland. Exiting through a gate, some road walking in a southerly direction brought them into Sully village and pounding pavements to reach the Jubilee Hall and the cricket field, the full beauty of Sully Bay with its views across the Bristol Channel towards the Somerset coastline and Hayes Point to the west confronted them.     With the wind beginning to pick up they tramped by track and field to the public slipway at Sully beach and stopped for lunch utilising rocks for seating whilst gazing eastwards towards Sully Island and Flat and Steep Holm beyond, as clouds thickened overhead and the temperature dropped making it feel more like autumn.Time to move on along part of the long distance Wales Coast Path, through the playing fields to exit onto Beach Road, following it to the car park of the Captainrsquos We where there were only a few people sitting at outdoor tables for food and drink, not really enjoyable in the cool breeze.The fairly quiet St Maryrsquos Well Bay Road brought them up past The Bay Caravan Park and into fields with growing crops where, without any warning a sudden short sharp shower of rain engulfed the group forcing coats to be swtly donned.Crossing a wooden footbridge into the delightful Lavernock Nature Reserve the grassy path led them into the remains of the WW gun emplacements. Initially in the late rsquos the original Lavernock Gun Battery was built to protect the Bristol and Cardf shipyards and the Bristol Channel, but unfortunately most of the original buildings now lie underneath the caravan park.Being bombarded by a short hail storm whilst moving on through the nature reserve, lovingly cared for by volunteers and passing the man-made pond with its surrounding carpet of bluish violet bugle, a plant which attracts moths, butterflies and bees, before exiting onto Fort Road their route led them past the Marconi Holiday Village and the Church of St Lawrence before heading along the clftop. With thick black clouds heading up the English side of the Bristol Channel, the race was on to get back before the rain hit. As the weather turned wintry and the wind increased, a huge shower of hailstones and heavy rain struck them on the open Penarth clftop soaking them as they made their way back to their start point.You can follow the grouprsquos exploits before, during and after lockdown on Facebook. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: sotm st richard gwyn catholic high school barry
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communitySt Richard GwynCatholic High School, on Argae Lane in Barry, has  pupils currently on roll, with this number increasing to  - the schoolrsquos biggest Year Seven cohort yet.Mr David Blackwell has been head teacher at the school since February , following his role as deputy head for more than four years.Headteacher Mr David BlackwellHe is backed by deputy head Matthew Dunn assistant headteachers Laura Burnettand Amy Leftleyand senior core leader Sharon Macleod.The schoolrsquos last Estyn report was in  ndash the school was rated lsquoadequatersquo overall but with good prospects of improvement.Explaining some of the improvements made since, Mr Blackwell said: ldquoWe have fully embedded the Jesuit Pupil Profile into the le of staff and students."The Jesuit Pupil Profile gives a focus to the citizens that we wish to nurture at SRG. It reminds staff and students that virtues towards the needs of others is paramount to the essence of our humanity."He continued: We have always prioritised wellbeing of our students but over the last two years we have developed a lsquowellbeing progress centre. Support staff have been trained extensively to ensure that all students are ready to learn.ldquoThe wellbeing team are always on hand to assist with the students wellbeing by offering sessions for ELSA, Thrive and Mental Health Wellbeing. We even have two wellbeing dogs that support some of our more vulnerable learners.ldquoWe work very closely with a iety of external agencies to support our students needs to ensure students are engaged and feel safe and secure and able to fulfil their full potential.The school caters to pupils with additional learning needs and to staff wellbeing. Staff at the school have training, progression opportunities, open door policy of support, and clear lines of communication.     ldquoTeaching and learning continues to be our core focus, added Mr Blackwell.ldquoThe  Inspection report praised students at SRG for lsquotheir positive attitude to learningrsquo. We have built upon this and we now offer a Scholarrsquos Programme to prepare students for their education pathway.ldquoWe want to offer students a chance to broaden their educational experience with us. We have broadened our option subjects at KS - we are now able to offer Construction, Health and Social Care and Textiles and Fashion.ldquoWe are committed to the promotion of SRG as a learning organisation. To this end we have entered into an ITE Partnership with Cardf politan University and an alliance with St.Illtydrsquos Catholic Comprehensive in Cardf. It is mutually beneficial since we help develop new teachers into the profession and we are able to utilise educational research to improve standards across both key stages.The Catholic school strives to ensures pupils succeed, while also being good people.ldquoWe aim for our pupils to live by the ethos of our pupil profile which is about virtues to empower them to be a success in le, added Mr Blackwell.ldquoWe are the faith secondary school of the Vale and so provide an excellent secondary education that runs equally alongside our holistic development of our pupils as iniduals and good all round people.The Catholic ethos is embedded into daily le at the school, with morning prayer, virtues-based assemblies, and daily reflection.ldquoAll staff engage in role modelling behaviour that reflects the Catholic virtues of honesty, integrity and forgiveness, added Mr Blackwell.ldquoDuring normal school times Mass is a frequent part of our school le ndash not all pupils come to us with a faith background, but they all appreciate the values that we try to weave into our everyday lives.Along with the schoolrsquos ethical focus St Richard Gwyn Catholic High School has an abundance of extra-curricular activities on offer, including school trips.Sporty youngsters can take part in football, rugby, netball, hockey, tennis, badminton, athletics, cheerleading and street dance. Therersquos also Clwb Cymraeg and an array of creative activities on offer ndash including art club, textiles club, choir, SRG band.Bi-annually the music, drama, and art departments join forces to produce and perform an arts production.St Richard Gwyn Catholic High School strives to form lsquopositive relationshipsrsquo with families and the local community and has a Facebook group regularly updated with video messages from Mr Blackwell and key messages for families.Each year group has a Progress Leader who is a point of contact for families as well as our Wellbeing and Progress Centre who liaises with families on a regular basis. Plus, St Richard Gwyn Catholic High School is in the process of obtaining the Investors in Families , which ndash in a nutshell ndash lsquois a quality mark that recognises the work that schools and other settings undertake with families to improve outcomes for children and young people.rsquoThe school is also lsquoproudrsquo to have worked with numerous charities ndash including fundraising for local food banks and helping Keep Wales Tidy with beach cleans.The school has also adapted a lsquogreatrsquo deal during the coronavirus pandemic ndash with the immediate priority being health and safety such as year group lsquobubblesrsquo, separate lunches, allocated outdoor spaces, regular sanitizing and face coverings.ldquoThe biggest impact, in terms of day to day operation, meant teachers moved more between lessons than students, said Mr Blackwell.ldquoCrucial to adapting to the pandemic was to adoption of online learning. There have been periods of lockdown with no pupils in school as well as fortnightly periods that have required year groups to isolate.He praised the training and use of online s as lsquotransformativersquo. and added that - while itrsquos lsquofantasticrsquo to resume in-person learning these changes and developments will continue to improve how the school operates.The school is lsquovery fortunatersquo to have been supported by the local authority to make the best of the buildings they have, but the school is awaiting progress on a new build under the st Century schools programme, financed by Welsh Government.ldquoWe firmly believe that what goes on inside school is more important than the way the building looks externally, said Mr Blackwell.ldquoWe have amazing staff who work exceptionally hard to make the best of the facilities we have, all pupils who come to us get a great educational experience.ldquoHowever, we are still awaiting progress on a new build. We will continue to work hard to improve our facilities with the support of our Governors and the local authority, but at the same time we will continue to lobby to get the new build progressed as soon as possible so that our pupils not only get a fantastic experience, but they also get it in state-of-the-art facilities they deserve. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: penarth pier pavilion turn similar venue cardiffs chapter arts centre
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityThe childrenrsquos section of Penarth Library will also move temporarily to the iconic art deco building on the Esplanade, which was recently taken over by Vale of Glamorgan council.More than a thousand people responded to a public consultation on what should happen next with the pavilion, with many supporting something similar to Chapter.Details of the responses to the consultation were revealed in a report to the councilrsquos cabinet, which meets on Wednesday, May , as well as the costs of recent repair work.The pavilion building first opened in . It was used for dances during the second world war, and a nightclub in the s and s. The building fell into disrepair about a decade ago, but a charity called Penarth Arts and Craft Limited spent lottery funding on renovation.Then the pavilion reopened in  as an arts and culture venue with a cinema, exhibition space, meeting rooms and a cafe. However, the charity later struggled with directors leaving and challenging trading conditions, particularly during the coronavirus pandemic.MORE NEWS:Towards the end of last year, the charity entered discussions with the Vale council and the National Lottery about what could be done. The council then took over control of the building last February, and asked the public for suggestions about how the pavilion should be used.A new cafe has opened in the pavilion, run by the councilrsquos armrsquosBig Fresh Catering Company. All profits from this company are put into providing healthy meals for schools.Essential repairs and maintenance have also been carried out on the building, including replacing the air conditioning repairing the lighting, fire doors, and gas boilers and testing the lt, water hygiene, and fire alarms. Initial works have cost about pound,.     The kitchen has also seen repairs and cleaning outside walls have been cleaned and the decking jet washed tables have been sanded and resealed and a broken window was replaced. Public wi has been improved and the cinema projector has been maintained.The childrenrsquos section of Penarth Library will temporarily be relocated to the pavilion. The section is currently not well ventilated enough to be Covid-secure, but it should be in the pavilion. Regular activities like Story Time will be held at the pavilion.The building could also soon host live music and a bar, as the council is applying for licences to play music and serve alcohol there.More than , people responded to a public consultation on what should happen next with the building from March  until April . Leguards will also provide cover over the school holidays at Aberystwyth South, Tresaith and Aberporth.In a survey,commissioned by the RNLI, % of those questioned - aged - - expect to visit a UK beach or the coast between April and September, with around half of that number likely to do so three or more times.A signicantly higher proportion of the publicalso said they plan to visit the coast more than usual this year, compared to  .Chris Cousens, RNLI Water Safety Lead in Wales says:"We are expecting this summer to be the busiest ever for our leguards and volunteer leboat crews in Wales and the survey figures back that up. With its stunning scenery and spectacular beaches, we are certain people will flock to the Welsh coastline and want people to enjoy it."We do however urge everyone to respect the water, think about their own safety and know what to do in an emergency.     "Our main advice is to visit a leguarded beach and swim between the red and yellow flags."RNLI leguards will be patrolling around  beaches this summer to offer advice on how to stay safe and they are also there to help anyone who gets into trouble."Whether yoursquore at a leguarded beach or not, look out for safety signage and seek advice on safe places to swim, keep your children under supervision at all times, avoid swimming alone where possible and know to alert the leguards or call  or  and ask for Coastguard in an emergency."Coastal areas provide a great opportunity to enjoy fresh air and open space but they can be an unpredictable environment, particularly during early summer when air temperatures start warming up but water temperatures remain very cold, increasing the risk of cold water shock."The key summer safety advice is:Visit a leguarded beach  swim between the red and yellow flagsIf you get into trouble Float to Live ndash lie on your back and relax, resisting the urge to thrash aboutCall  or  in an emergency and ask for the CoastguardNot everyone who finds themselves in trouble in the water, expected to even get wet. title: bethan roper inquest jury hears friends
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityBethan Roper, , suffered fatal head injuries while a passenger on the Great Western Railwaytravelling at around mph.Miss Roper, of Penarth, was ing home to South Wales from a day out with friends Christmas shopping in Bath.Avon Coronerrsquos Court heard Miss Roper and her three friends, Elizabeth Winstone Evans, Chanelle Hagland and Madeleine Owens, had boarded the train at Bath Spa station on the evening of December , .The GWR London Paddington to Exeter service was using carriages fitted with droplight windows to enable passengers to use the handle on the outside when they needed to leave the train at the .Investigators told the inquest that the warning label above the window, a yellow sticker with the words: lsquoCaution do not lean out of window when train is movingrsquo, was not a sufficient deterrent.Miss Roper was fatally injured just a few minutes after the train left Bath when her head was struck by an ash tree branch growing on land adjacent to the line.PC Kate Aldred, of British Transport Police, spoke with Miss Hagland when the train arrived at Bristol Temple Meads station shortly after the incident and made written notes of the conversation.ldquoThe train had been travelling five or six minutes when Miss Evans opened the pulldown window of the door, Pc Aldred said.ldquoMiss Evans leant her head out of the window very slightly for about  seconds and then said something like, lsquoGirls try thisrsquo.ldquoMiss Evans put her head back inside the carriage and then Miss Roper has immediately stepped forward and put her head right out of the window.ldquoMiss Hagland was sat on the floor close to Miss Roperrsquos legs.ldquoMiss Roperrsquos head must only have been out for five seconds when Miss Hagland heard the sound of an impact.ldquoMiss Roper fell backwards towards Miss Hagland and caught Miss Roper.     ldquoMiss Roper then fell forwards and slumped onto the floor.Later, Miss Hagland told police in a statement that by the time they caught the train they were not ldquodrunk or disorderly.ldquoWersquove all had a quite a few drinks but we are used to drinking like that.ldquoWe had all sobered up by then and drunk ourselves sober, she told officers.Describing the minutes before the incident, Miss Hagland said they were all in the vestibule area of the train as it was busy and her friend Miss Evans pulled down the window of the door as she was hot.ldquoLizzy leant her head out of the window just slightly and her hair was blowing, Miss Hagland said.ldquoI think Lizzy was hot and I didnrsquot even know those windows go down.ldquoI heard Lizzy say, lsquolook at this girlsrsquo and when she pulled in Beth charged over and did exactly the same thing and she put her head out just a little bit more than Lizzy did.ldquoFrom what I can remember the shoulders were still in the carriage.ldquoI was just about to stand up when the branch hit her head.ldquoIt was pretty much straight awayhellip five seconds.ldquoShe kind of took two steps back and stumbled and fell right into me and fell forward.A post-mortem examination found Miss Roper had died from head injuries.Toxicology tests found she had a blood alcohol level of mg in ml of blood, meaning she was nearly twice the drink drive limit.Miss Roper worked for the Welsh Refugee Council charity and was chairwoman of Young Socialists Cardf.The hearing continues. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityJonathan Adams, died on Friday, May  at the age of  after a short illness.As well as running Ashtons fishmonger in Cardf market, Jonathan was also known for being part owner of Potters Corner and president of the National Federation of Fishmongers for three years.Emma Enos, Jonathanrsquos partner of  years, said there wasnrsquot a day that the pair didnrsquot speak to one another. Emma and Jonathan have been together since . Picture: Emma EnosldquoI was lucky enough to have over  years with him, and with the exception of recently when he was poorly, there wasnrsquot a day where we didnrsquot speak to each other, she added.Jonathan changed the Ashton fishmonger businesses around. Ashtons used to be around  per cent market trade ndash where the customers came from ndash but he soon realised that would change due to the bigger supermarkets.So, he began to get involved in catering and supplying restaurants across South Wales, which now makes up the majority of the businesses.One of the last gigs Jonathan went to was the Genesis gig at Milton Keynes Bowl. Picture: Ashton fishmonger on FacebookldquoBeing a fth generation fishmonger, he was very passionate about the businesses ndash he was in six days a week, added Miss Enos.ldquoHe might not have done full days in recent times but he was usually in first thing in the morning and then perhaps home by  or , but it was still a huge part of his le.ldquoHe was very passionate about the staff and customers and getting it right.ldquoHis father made him be a Saturday boy and made sure he learned how to do all the filleting and everything .Jonathan was very big into horse racing ndash starting with the White Hart racing club ndash and more recently, with JJ Quinn, co-owned several horses with Christian Williams in a consortium ndash including Potterrsquos Corner who won the virtual grand national last year.Jonathan Adams - an active member of the sports clubs, particularly Glamorganshire Golf Club. Picture: Emma EnosPaying tribute to her partner, Miss Enos said: ldquoEven when he was poorly, not only would he have restaurateurs ringing asking how he was but he would have inidual customers, and I think that shows his passion but also how much he was thought of.     ldquoHe very much had personal relationships with regular customers, making sure they were looked after the same way he would be looking after a big restaurant.MORE NEWS:ldquoNothing was too much trouble for him, he was a stickler for detail and getting things right.ldquoIf he was your friend, he was loyal but hersquod tell you like it is and people just would gravitate towards him.ldquoIt sounds clicheacute but yoursquod know when he had arrived and he would be the centre of attention.Jonathan has two brothers, Simon Adams and Nicky Adams, who currently still works at Ashfords in Cardf.Simon said he would often attend gigs around Penarth with Jonathan when they got a bit older.ldquoHe got really into all of the New Wave and Punk stuff and that has been a huge influence on me even today, he said.ldquoHe was a very humorous man. He was into comedy in the sense that he was a really funny person.ldquoHe loved le and was dead set on living his le in every sense of the word. He was astute, witty, and would do anything for anyone.The family understand that Jonathan wasvery well-known across the town and that many may want to pay their respects, but given that there are limited numbers allowed to attend the service they are asking for people not to turn up to the service unless invited.They have made alternative arrangements to allow more people to remember Jonathan. ldquoBike Week is a great opportunity to dust off that old bike and take it out for a spin.ldquoThere are a range of activities available for people to enjoy over the seven days.ldquoCycling is not when taking certain trips is a simple way to achieve that.OTHER NEWS:Studies suggest people who cycle regularly in adulthood enjoy a level of fitness equivalent to someone  years younger.There are a story: Traffic Attendants back on streets next week   Toddler, who died in tragic incident, is named locallyNewsTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthPeopleRead ThisCoronavirusSportFootballOther SportWhats OnArts and EntertainmentThings To DoHomes and GardensLestyleCarsHomes and GardensPublic NoticesAdvertise My BusinessNewsPeopleBlockbuster movies ready for Omniplex reopeningMovie buffs will be delighted that the local Omniplex chain is all set to reopen to the public next Monday - pending the easing of Lockdown restrictions.By Carmel RobinsonMonday, th May , : pm  "       "  Ready to roll out the reels, the Omniplex Cinemas are awaiting official confirmation from the NI Executive - which is due on Thursday .The cinema chain plans to begin its phased reopening of five sites, with Omniplex Craigavon Lisburn, Dundonald, Newry and Bangor welcoming customers back to a covid safe way from this date. Eight more Omniplex locations across the country are ready to resume screening from Friday th May marking the first time this year for avid movie goers to enjoy the big screen experience. ]]Craigavon Omniplex.The cinema chain – the largest in NI, closed all of its venues on December , , when all areas of the UK and Ireland were under pandemic restrictions. Paul John Anderson, Director of Omniplex Cinemas said: “We are thrilled to finally be welcoming back cinema goers for the first time this year. We strongly believe in the power of escapism that a couple of hours spent at the cinema provides and we are looking forward to opening our doors for the ultimate big screen experience. We have worked hard over the last year to ensure our customers can enjoy the magic of cinema once again. We continue to follow public health advice and the safety of our team and customers remains of utmost importance.” Safety measures will include limited capacity m distance between parties for social distancing requirements face coverings to be worn by staff and audiences when moving within cinema buildings and staggered showtimes to name a few. Omniplex Cinemas will also be operating enhanced online booking to make the visit as contactless as possible with increased cleaning regimes and hand sanitising stations in every foyer. Visitors will be expected to wear face masks but will be allowed to remove them when seated in auditoriums for eating or drinking. Paul added: “It’s been a long and dficult year for us all with restrictions affecting our daily lives. We know that our audiences are eager to get back to the big screen and we cannot wait to see people experiencing the cinema once again.” Several film studios had paused the release of their ‘tentpole’ blockbusters in , opting for release dates in the latter half of . From th May, film fans can enjoy films including Peter Rabbit , voiced by stars including James Corden and Margot Robbie and much-anticipated horror film The Conjuring . A raft of blockbuster films is set to be released in this summer with Marvel releasing the much-delayed Black Widow on th July. DC Comics will play to a similar field of movie goers with the release of The Suicide Squad on th August. The ninth instalment of Fast and Furious will come to cinema screens across NI on th July this year. The th James Bond will also grace the movie screens with No Time to Die featuring Daniel Craig as  expected to come out on th September in the UK and Ireland. Tickets are on sale now in advance of these reopening dates at www.omniplex.ie. The remaining sites in Derry, Belfast, Antrim, Carrickfergus, Omagh, Downpatrick, Banbridge and Dungannon will open again from Friday th May. Omniplex is the largest cinema chain in Ireland, with over  screens in  locations.
